Text: 

Some time ago, a website talked about the risks of public check-ins, which are online posts about where you are. The website's message was clear: when you say, "Hey, I’m at this place," you are also telling many people where you are, including some you might not want to meet. This shows that sharing everything online can have negative effects. The internet gives us many chances to share our lives with a large audience, which can seem exciting: wealth, fame, and more. But as we share personal stories and photos, we might find ourselves in a crowded and dangerous space online.

This situation might seem sad, but there is hope. A long time ago, a group of early internet users, known as online pioneers, explored these challenges. They faced many problems, like losing jobs and friends, long before social media existed. These pioneers, who we now call bloggers, have already experienced what many of us are going through today. It is important to learn from their experiences.

In January 1994, Justin Hall, a 19-year-old student, started posting on the web, which was mostly used by graduate students and scientists. The web was created at CERN, a physics lab in Switzerland, to help researchers share their work. Hall saw a chance to share his own life. He created a personal website filled with stories, photos, and art. In January 1996, he began a daily blog, and many people were interested in his adventures as he explored this new way of sharing.

Hall was open about everything; if you crossed his path, you could end up on his site. While some might see this as attention-seeking, there was also a unique beauty to his work. However, one day, visitors to his site found it replaced by a video called Dark Night. Hall shared that he had fallen in love, but when he wrote about it, he was told, "either the blog goes, or I do." He felt that sharing his life online made people distrust him. The blog ended, but the problem of sharing online remains. Sharing online can be fun, but if you think it will make people want to be with you, you might be disappointed.

In 2002, Heather Armstrong, a young worker in Los Angeles, had a blog called Dooce. She sometimes wrote about her job at a software company. One day, a colleague sent her blog link to the company’s vice presidents, including some she had made fun of, and she lost her job. Experts call this the "online distribution effect," which means people often say things online that they would never say in person. However, the internet is not a separate world where we can say anything without consequences. Our online lives are connected to our real lives, and pretending otherwise can lead to serious mistakes.

Armstrong's story had a happy ending. Although she was upset and stopped blogging for a while, she later got married and started a new blog about her family. Today, she is popular among "mommy bloggers," and her writing helps support her family. Once known for her online mistakes, she has learned to share her life carefully. What Armstrong teaches us is important: the internet lets us say anything, but that doesn’t mean we should.

Text: 

Some scientists started a campaign to warn people about a low-budget film called What the Bleep Do We Know? This film mixes documentary and drama to show that there is a lot about our universe that we do not understand. How can any scientist argue with that? Scientists can sometimes be a bit arrogant, but even the most confident physicist would not say they know everything about the universe. Still, some scientists felt they needed to warn the public about the film, calling it things like ‘atrocious’ and ‘very dangerous’. This made me curious to see the movie.

At first, I did not understand why there was so much excitement about it. Various scientists made simple statements about how new discoveries were showing that the universe is stranger than we thought. However, when the film talked about some of these discoveries, I began to see why people were interested. One claim was that water molecules can be affected by thoughts. I had heard before that a Japanese researcher showed that the shape of a water molecule could change based on the thoughts of people around it. But the movie only showed pictures of ice crystals that looked nice after being talked to by happy people and ugly after being exposed to angry people. 

Many people find this kind of evidence convincing because it is clear and easy to understand. However, scientists often respond with skepticism. They want more proof. The idea that water can be affected by thoughts is amazing, but we need solid evidence to believe it. Pretty pictures of crystals are not enough. 

The real issue is that the movie’s claims were not strange enough. For example, some scientists say that water molecules have properties linked to a mysterious energy that seems to come from nowhere. This energy is connected to a force that is making the universe expand. The evidence for this comes from many years of research in labs and observatories around the world. 

Discoveries are being made that show the universe is stranger than we ever thought. Astronomers have found that the universe is made of an unknown type of matter and is driven by a mysterious force called ‘dark energy’. 

On a more everyday level, scientists have made amazing discoveries too. Neuroscientists found that our awareness of events happens about half a second after they actually occur. We do not notice this delay because our brains edit it out. Anthropologists believe they have found where modern humans first appeared and how they spread across the world. Some theorists even suggest there are links between life on Earth and the design of the universe.

Despite what some people think, science is not finished. In fact, we seem to know less than we thought. Many natural events cannot be understood as we once believed. The ideas of chaos and quantum uncertainty show that there are limits to what we can know. Some of the best theoretical physicists are trying to create a Theory of Everything, which would explain all the forces and particles in the universe with one equation. 

In the end, many of us believe that the universe can be described in one word: incredible.

Text: "In simple terms, I find writing novels challenging, but writing short stories is a joy. If writing novels is like planting a forest, then writing short stories is like planting a garden. Both types of writing help each other, creating a beautiful landscape that I love. The trees provide shade, and the wind moves the leaves, which can turn a bright gold. In the garden, flowers bloom, and colorful petals attract bees and butterflies, showing the change of seasons.

Since I started my career as a fiction writer, I have often switched between writing novels and short stories. My pattern is this: after I finish a novel, I want to write short stories; after I finish a group of short stories, I want to focus on a novel. I never write short stories while writing a novel, and I never write a novel while working on short stories. The two types of writing use different parts of my brain, and it takes time to switch from one to the other.

I began my career with two short novels in 1975, and from 1984 to 1985, I started writing short stories. I knew little about writing short stories then, so it was difficult, but I found the experience memorable. I felt my fictional world expand, and readers seemed to enjoy this different side of me as a writer. One of my early works, ‘Breaking Waves’, was included in my first short-story collection, Tales from Abroad. This was my beginning as a short-story writer.

One joy of writing short stories is that they don’t take long to finish. Usually, it takes me about a week to get a short story into good shape (though I can revise it many times). It’s not like the long commitment needed for a novel, which can take a year or two. For me, writing a novel can feel endless, and I sometimes wonder if I will finish. So, writing short stories is a nice change of pace.

Another good thing about short stories is that you can create a story from the smallest ideas – a thought, a word, an image, or anything. It’s often like jazz improvisation, where the story takes me where it wants to go. Also, with short stories, you don’t have to worry about failing. If an idea doesn’t work out, you can just accept it and move on. Even great writers like F. Scott Fitzgerald and Raymond Carver didn’t write a masterpiece every time. This gives me comfort. You can learn from your mistakes and use that knowledge in your next story.

When I write novels, I try to learn from both the successes and failures I have in writing short stories. In this way, short stories are like a testing ground for me as a novelist. It is hard to experiment in the way I like within a novel, so without short stories, writing novels would be even more difficult.

My short stories are like soft shadows I have placed in the world, faint footprints I have left behind. I remember exactly where I wrote each one and how I felt. Short stories are like guideposts to my heart, and it makes me happy as a writer to share these personal feelings with my readers."

Text: 

Science is a way of understanding the world. It can help us cure diseases and improve our lives, but it can also create problems. Science tries to explain everything from tiny atoms to the vast universe. It has influenced many areas of life, including art, politics, and philosophy. Sometimes, people do not understand its dangers or importance, and they may either overestimate or underestimate it. 

The history of science is full of disagreements. Old ideas are often changed or replaced by new ones. Just like in music, new ideas in science can be laughed at before they become accepted. Scientists can be very competitive, and jealousy and anger are common feelings among them. 

This book will focus on important scientific ideas that have changed how we think. While science has practical uses, we will mainly look at its ideas and their beauty. We will also remember that science can be limited and that our understanding can change. 

Science is always changing. There is always a scientist who is proving another scientist wrong. Most of the time, these changes do not affect society much. However, sometimes, big changes can challenge our beliefs. For example, in the 1600s, scientists began to see the universe as a giant machine. Later, new discoveries made us question this view. 

Some people think that the changing nature of science shows that it cannot explain the universe. But often, these changes help us understand and predict nature better. For instance, Isaac Newton explained more about the world than the ancient Greek thinker Aristotle, and Albert Einstein explained even more than Newton. 

Science can make mistakes, but it keeps moving forward. At the end of the 1800s, many physicists thought there was nothing new to discover. Then, new ideas like radioactivity, X-rays, and quantum mechanics changed everything. Biology has also made many discoveries. 

Today, some people believe we are close to finding a complete explanation of the universe. Science is not just a fun activity; it has real effects on our lives. In the last 200 years, we have gone from simply observing nature to controlling it in some ways. This has sometimes upset the balance of nature. 

Everyone needs to understand science because it affects our future and the world our children will live in. The decisions made in science can impact many important things, like health and the environment. Science is now a key part of how we think about and shape our future.

**Simplified Text:**

Since around 2015, after many years of growth, big publishers started to say that ebook sales had stopped growing or even decreased in some cases. This raised questions about the future of ebooks in the publishing world. One publishing executive even said that the excitement about ebooks might have led to bad investments, making his company lose faith in the value of printed books. 

Even though it seems clear that ebooks and printed books can exist together, people still ask if ebooks will replace printed books. Whether people want to predict this or deny it, the idea that books might disappear continues to spark our imagination and create strong discussions. Why is this idea so strong? Why do we see the relationship between ebooks and printed books as a fight, even when evidence shows they can coexist? The answers to these questions go beyond ebooks and reveal much about our feelings of excitement and fear regarding change and new technology.

In my research, I have looked at how the idea of one type of media replacing another often happens when new technologies are introduced. Even before digital technology, people predicted that new inventions would end older forms of media. For example, when television was invented, many thought radio would disappear. However, radio found new ways to be used, like being listened to in cars and on trains.

The idea that books might disappear is not new either. As early as 1894, people thought that the phonograph would replace books with what we now call audiobooks. This pattern has happened many times. Movies, radio, television, hyperlinks, and smartphones have all been said to threaten printed books at different times. Some people believed that the end of books would lead to a decline in culture, while others thought that ebooks would bring a better future.

The idea of books disappearing often comes up during times of technological change. This idea reflects our mixed feelings of hope and fear about new technology. To understand why we feel this way, we need to think about how we form emotional connections with different types of media, which become important in our lives. Many studies show that we can feel close to objects like books, televisions, and computers, even naming our cars or getting frustrated with our laptops.

When new technology, like e-readers, appears, it doesn’t just mean economic and social change. It also makes us rethink our connection with things that are part of our daily lives. As technology changes, we often miss what we used to know. This is why industries grow around older products and technologies. For example, when the printing press spread in 15th-century Europe, people wanted original manuscripts. The change from silent to sound movies in the 1920s made people nostalgic for the older style. The same happened when photography changed from analog to digital and from vinyl records to CDs. 

E-readers have also made people appreciate the physical qualities of printed books, even their smell. This should comfort those who worry about printed books disappearing. However, the idea of disappearing media will continue to be an interesting story about how technology changes and our fear of change. One way we try to understand change is by using familiar stories, like those of tragedy and endings. The story of the death of the book is easy to remember and share, reflecting both our excitement for the future and our fear of losing parts of our familiar world – and ultimately, ourselves.

Text: 

For a year and a half, I woke up at 5:30 every weekday morning. I brushed my teeth, made a cup of coffee, and sat down to write about how some of the greatest thinkers of the last four hundred years managed their time. I wanted to understand how they organized their days to be creative and productive. By writing about the everyday details of their lives – when they slept, ate, worked, and worried – I hoped to show a different side of their personalities and careers. 

The French writer Jean Anthelme Brillat-Savarin once said, “Tell me what you eat, and I shall tell you what you are.” I believe, “Tell me what time you eat, and whether you take a nap afterward.” This book is not just about the creative work itself, but about the daily habits that help people be creative. It is also personal. The writer John Cheever said that you can’t even write a business letter without showing something about yourself. 

I have my own questions: How can you do meaningful creative work while also making a living? Is it better to focus completely on one project or to work a little each day? When there is not enough time, do you have to give up things like sleep or a clean house, or can you learn to do more in less time? I do not have all the answers, but I want to share how many successful people have faced similar challenges. 

The title of the book is Daily Rituals, but I really focus on people’s routines. A routine can seem ordinary, but it can also help you use your time, willpower, and optimism wisely. A good routine can help you stay focused and avoid being affected by your moods. The psychologist William James believed that having good habits allows us to focus on more interesting things. Ironically, he was a procrastinator and struggled to keep a regular schedule.

This book started because of my own procrastination. One Sunday afternoon, I was at the small architecture magazine where I worked, trying to write a story that was due the next day. Instead of working, I was cleaning my desk and making coffee. I am a “morning person,” so I can focus well in the morning but not in the afternoon. To feel better about this, I began searching online for information about other writers’ schedules. I found many interesting stories and thought it would be great to collect them. This led to the Daily Routines blog I started that day and now this book.

The blog was simple; I shared descriptions of people’s routines from biographies, magazine articles, and obituaries. For the book, I have gathered more detailed and researched information while keeping the variety of voices that made the blog interesting. I have let my subjects speak for themselves through quotes from their letters, diaries, and interviews. In some cases, I summarized their routines from other sources. 

I want to thank the many biographers, journalists, and scholars whose work helped me. I have listed all my sources in the Notes section, which I hope will help you find more to read.

**Simplified Text:**

Howard became a palaeontologist because of a change in interest rates when he was six years old. His father, who was careful with money and had a big loan, said that their planned holiday to Spain was not possible anymore. Instead, they rented a small house on the English coast. One rainy August afternoon, Howard found an ammonite on the beach. He had always wanted to be a palaeontologist, and by the end of university, he knew what kind he wanted to be. He was not interested in dinosaurs or the Jurassic period. Instead, he was fascinated by the very beginning of life on Earth. He studied small creatures found in grey rocks.

When he finished his doctoral thesis, he wondered if he would get a job. He felt confident about his abilities, but he knew that hard work does not always lead to success. The process of getting a job in academia can be difficult. When the Assistant Lectureship at Tavistock College in London was available, he applied, but he did not expect much.

On the day of Howard’s interview, the professor who was supposed to lead the panel had a fight with his wife. He left home upset, crashed his car into a gatepost, and ended up in the hospital. The interview happened without him, and the professor who replaced him did not like Howard’s former professor. This new professor helped Howard get the job. Howard was surprised and grateful, but later a colleague explained what really happened. Howard felt a little disappointed. He wished he could think that he was chosen because of his skills, but he was just happy to have the job and do the work he loved.

Howard often thought about how organized his work life was, where he could plan and follow through, compared to the chaos of his personal life. Many people can affect your life, and sometimes a stranger can change everything. This happened to Howard when his briefcase, which had his lecture notes, was stolen at a train station. Angry, Howard went back to the college, called to explain, and postponed his lecture. He reported the theft and then went for a coffee. There, he met a colleague who was with a visitor from the Natural History Museum in Nairobi. Howard learned about a new collection of fossils that needed to be studied, which would be a big challenge for him and help his career. Because of the theft, he changed his plans. He decided not to go to a conference in Stockholm or take students on a trip to Scotland. Instead, he would find a way to visit the museum in Nairobi.

Text: Charles Spence will eat almost anything. "We have ice cream made from bee larvae at home," says the Professor of Experimental Psychology at Oxford University in the UK. They may look like maggots, but they have a "slightly nutty, floral" taste. One of the challenges Spence and his team are working on is how to make eating bugs acceptable. Through his studies on how our senses work together to create flavor, Spence is quietly influencing what we eat and drink. This includes the products of big food companies and the menus of top restaurants. Spence and his colleagues study how we experience food and drink in detail. Many factors affect taste, such as who we eat with, how food is arranged, the color and weight of plates and cutlery, and background noise. Spence’s book, The Perfect Meal, co-written with Betina Piqueras-Fiszman, is full of interesting facts about food. For example, did you know that the first person to order in a restaurant enjoys their food more? And we eat about 35% more food when dining with one other person, and 75% more with three others. 

Spence’s lab in Oxford is simple and not high-tech. He has soundproof booths that look like large safes, and old audio-visual equipment. By keeping costs low, he can work creatively with chefs who cannot pay for research. Much of his work is funded by a large food company. In the past, research funded by industry was seen as less important in universities. But now, since the government wants universities to show their work has an impact, this type of research is considered valuable. Spence is helping famous brands reduce salt and sugar in their products. It is important for these companies to help their customers live longer. Surprisingly, many companies have been making these changes quietly, so customers do not notice. "Research shows that when you tell people what you are doing, they focus on the taste and often do not like it as much," he says.

Spence first met Heston Blumenthal, a famous experimental chef, while working on a project for a big food company. At that time, people thought combining science and food was strange, but most food is scientific. Blumenthal helped change this view. Together, they created the "Sound of the Sea" dish in Blumenthal’s five-star restaurant. Interestingly, Spence notes that artists from the early 1900s were already experimenting with sounds and food, but it did not become popular. Now, the food industry is using Spence’s research on the senses in many products. For example, higher-pitched music can make food taste sweeter, while lower-pitched sounds can make it taste bitter. "It is surprising how shapes can affect taste, or how a song can change how you feel about a flavor," he says. An airline will soon match music with the food served to passengers. Last year, a well-known brand released an app that played music while your ice cream melts, but they did not match the music to the taste, which often happens according to Spence.

What are dinner parties like at Spence's home? Once, they had rabbit with the fur around the cutlery. Another time, they played with remote-controlled, colorful light bulbs. "We’ve had dinner parties with a tone generator, headphones, and ten different drinks to see if they have different pitches." For Spence, home, sweet shops, food conventions, and international food conferences are all part of his research.

**Simplified Text:**

Our brains are busier than ever. We are bombarded with facts, false information, and rumors that we must sort through to find what is important and what we can ignore. At the same time, we are doing more things ourselves. Thirty years ago, travel agents helped us book flights, and salespeople helped us find items in stores. Now, we do most of these tasks on our own. We are trying to manage many responsibilities, like our families, jobs, hobbies, and favorite TV shows, often with the help of our smartphones. These devices have become part of our busy lives, where we try to fit as much as possible into every free moment.

However, there is a problem. Even though we think we are multitasking—doing many things at once—this is a misleading idea. Earl Miller, a neuroscientist at MIT, says our brains are not good at multitasking. When we think we are multitasking, we are actually switching quickly from one task to another. Each time we switch, it costs us mental energy. We are not like expert jugglers; we are more like people trying to keep many plates spinning, worried that one will fall.

Even though we believe we are getting a lot done, multitasking makes us less efficient. It can increase stress hormones in our bodies, which can make us feel confused or foggy. Multitasking can also create a craving for constant stimulation, making it hard to focus. The part of our brain that helps us stay focused can easily be distracted by new things, like shiny objects that attract our attention.

Just having the chance to multitask can hurt our ability to think clearly. Glenn Wilson, a psychology professor, found that trying to focus on a task while seeing an unread email can lower our IQ by almost 10 points. He showed that the mental losses from multitasking are even worse than those caused by being tired. Russ Poldrack, a neuroscientist at Stanford, found that learning while multitasking can send information to the wrong part of the brain. For example, if students do homework while watching TV, the information may not be stored properly, making it harder to remember later.

Multitasking also involves making decisions, like whether to answer a text message or ignore it. Making decisions is hard for our brains, and small decisions can use as much mental energy as big ones. After making many small decisions, we can end up making poor choices about important matters.

In discussions about information overload, email is often mentioned as a problem. It is not that email itself is bad, but the huge amount of messages we receive can be overwhelming. When a 10-year-old boy was asked what his father does, he said, "He answers emails." His father agreed that this was quite true. We feel we must reply to emails, but it often feels impossible to do that and accomplish anything else.

**Simplified Text:**

In a zoo in Sweden, a chimpanzee named Santino spent his nights breaking concrete into pieces to throw at visitors during the day. Was he being mean? In caves in the US, female bats help other fruit bat mothers if they can’t find the right way to give birth. Are they being kind? Fifty years ago, people thought these questions were not important. Animals had behaviors, and science studied those behaviors. The idea that animals have thoughts, feelings, and morals was seen as silly. But this has started to change. Research on bats, chimps, rats, dolphins, and chickens has begun to explore animal emotions. This change has appeared in some popular science books, like Mark Bekoff’s *Wild Justice* and Victoria Braithwaite’s *Do Fish Feel Pain?* This has started a debate that may never be answered: do animals have consciousness? This debate leads to another question: do animals have a sense of right and wrong that guides their behavior? 

In a recent experiment with cows, those that opened a locked gate to get food showed more happiness by jumping and kicking than those that had the gate opened for them. If cows enjoy solving problems, what does this mean for how we produce and eat beef? While the observations are clear, how we interpret them is not. Dr. Jonathan Balcombe, who wrote *Second Nature*, believes we should stop eating meat. He thinks humanity is close to a big change in ethics, similar to the end of slavery. Aubrey Manning, a professor at Edinburgh University, believes we should rethink how we view animal intelligence. He says animals likely have a simpler understanding of the world than humans. Professor Euan MacPhail thinks we should stop attributing human feelings to animals. These three views may never agree because the main issue is not just scientific or moral, but philosophical. Since it is very hard to define consciousness, can we ever know what it is like to be a bat? 

Balcombe describes an important experiment he did that seems to show that starlings, a type of bird, can feel depressed. In a study at Newcastle University, starlings were divided into two groups. One group lived in nice cages with plenty of space and water, while the other group lived in small, empty cages. Both groups learned to eat tasty worms from one box and avoid unpleasant worms from another. But when only unpleasant worms were offered, only the starlings in nice cages would eat. Balcombe concluded that living in a bad cage made the starlings feel negative about life. Balcombe, who has worked with animal rights groups, has a strong opinion. He says, “We look back with disgust at a time when there was racism. One day, our view of animals will be the same. We can’t support animal rights while eating a cheeseburger.” 

If Balcombe were the only one with this view, it might be easy to ignore him. But Professor Aubrey Manning shares similar ideas. Manning has written a textbook called *An Introduction to Animal Behaviour*. He says, “What we are seeing is a swing in ideas. In the early 20th century, some people thought animals thought just like us, and then there was a reaction against that. Now we are moving back to the idea that animals have feelings. But this is a complicated topic, and we should be careful about listening to academics with strong personal opinions.”

Critical thinking is a way to understand what we read or hear more deeply. Adrian West, a research director at the Edward de Bono Foundation in the U.K., believes that arguing can help us find the truth. While technology helps us store and process information, there are worries that it also changes how we solve complex problems and makes it harder to think clearly. West says we are often exposed to poor thinking and popular opinions that can confuse us. Even though we have more information than ever, it does not always lead to better knowledge or decisions. 

According to the National Endowment for the Arts, fewer people are reading literature, and this decline is getting faster. Patricia Greenfield, a psychology professor, thinks that focusing more on visual media, like videos, may hurt our critical thinking skills. She says we are more focused on real-time media and multitasking instead of concentrating on one thing. However, we still do not have a clear answer about how technology affects critical thinking. 

Technology has changed how we think, and it can have both positive and negative effects. For example, a computer game might help us think critically or make it harder to do so. Reading online can improve our analysis skills, but clicking on many links can distract us from deeper thinking. Greenfield has studied how learning and technology interact and found that reading helps us think and use our imagination better than visual media like video games and TV. Reading develops our imagination, reflection, and vocabulary. However, she also found that some visual media can help with processing information. Unfortunately, most visual media do not give us time to think or reflect.

As a result, many young people may not reach their full potential. How society views technology affects how we think about critical thinking. The debate about video games and thinking is a clear example. James Paul Gee, a professor of educational psychology, says that many people believe video games are bad for kids. However, he argues that they can be a good learning tool. Evidence shows that playing video games can help children develop better reasoning skills. Games like Sim City and Civilization teach decision-making and analytical skills in fun, virtual environments that are similar to the real world. These games also allow players to explore ideas that they might not be able to in real life. 

In today’s digital age, as reading and math scores go down, we need to look more closely at technology and understand how it affects our thinking and analysis.

Text: 

Matthew Crawford is a motorcycle mechanic and a writer. He chose this job after feeling unhappy with office work and social policy jobs. His first book talked about the good things about manual work. His latest book is about how to deal with modern life. He got the idea for this book while shopping. He saw advertisements on a credit card machine while he was entering his pin number. Crawford realized that it is hard to avoid these distractions. What we think about at any moment is personal, but we often cannot choose this because of things we do not notice. It is becoming harder to think or remember conversations. People try to avoid being interrupted, so they stop talking to strangers. Crawford says, “We see the world through things that are made for us, like video games and apps.” These things reflect our desires and take over our attention.

Crawford is not alone in his worries. Many office workers complain about emails but still check them in their free time. Studies show that just seeing a phone can make it hard to focus. There is no clear evidence yet that our attention spans are shorter, but people are more aware of other things they could be doing. Some think this problem is caused by technology, but Crawford believes technology helps us focus too much on ourselves. With so many choices, it is hard to control ourselves, which affects our social lives. People prefer to text friends instead of talking to them. Crawford argues that by only interacting with screens instead of real people, we might lose something important in society.

He gives an example from his gym. There used to be one music player for everyone, which could cause disagreements. Now, people listen to their own music with earbuds. “The gym used to be a social place, but it has lost that,” he says. Real connections often happen when people have different opinions and work through them together.

Crawford suggests two solutions. First, we need to reduce noise and distractions in public places. More importantly, he believes we should engage in skilled activities to connect with the world better. He mentions cooks, ice-hockey players, and motorbike racers as examples of people who deal with real things. No video can replace the feeling of a hockey puck on ice or gravel under a motorbike. These activities require good judgment and the ability to interact with others.

Crawford says, “When you engage with the world this way, fake experiences seem less important.” He does not mean everyone should become a chef, but it is important to use your judgment. There are many benefits to this, including feeling satisfied with your work. Constantly fighting distractions can be tiring and make it harder to focus on what is important. In contrast, paying attention to one thing can help you pay attention to others.

Text: 

"What do you do for a living?" This is a common question in small talk, and we often define ourselves by our jobs. However, if you are a philosopher, like me, it can be a bit more complicated. Saying you are a philosopher can sound pretentious. It is okay to say you study or teach philosophy, but calling yourself a philosopher might make people think you believe you know some special truth. This is not true; philosophers are just like everyone else. 

One reason people think this way is that philosophers often judge what others do and celebrate thinking. The Greek philosopher Aristotle (384 – 322 BCE) said that a life of thinking, or a philosophical life, is the best kind of life. Many modern philosophers do not agree, but philosophy is still seen as connected to deep thinking. Another Greek philosopher, Socrates, said that "the unexamined life is not worth living." This means that simply accepting what society says can lead to an unsatisfying life. Our ability to think about the world helps us control our lives and make our own choices.

However, living an examined life does not mean you have to read many philosophical books or spend all your time thinking. It just means paying more attention to the everyday experiences that shape our lives. You do not have to be a wise person living away from society to do this. In fact, examining our lives can be very practical and should involve sharing knowledge, as it is important for a good life.

Another reason people misunderstand philosophers is that academic philosophy has become more separate from real-life experiences, especially for those who do not have formal training. This is not only the philosophers' fault; university funding and evaluations are often linked to expensive academic journals. Because of this, philosophers have little chance to share their ideas with anyone outside their small group of experts. For many people, philosophy can seem far away from reality. While some philosophers used to challenge this view, many have stopped. The university system has created a situation where academics are isolated, and they often support this separation. As philosophy has become focused on very specific debates, it has become harder for those outside the field to understand, and even more so for those without training.

This trend needs to change. I sometimes call myself an "ethicist" because I mostly work in ethics, which is the part of philosophy that looks at human actions. Recently, I have felt that this title does not fully describe my work because ethics is often seen as related to formal rules and laws. There is a new way of thinking in ethics that looks at the fairness of specific social practices. The job of an ethicist today is to decide if certain actions are "ethical" or acceptable. These are important questions that I think about often.

However, philosophy is more than just this. A typical discussion might start by asking if illegally downloading movies is unethical (it is) and then move on to questions about responsibility, our views on art, and the effects of consumerism. In this way, philosophy can help people think more deeply about the actions and behaviors that shape their lives. Sometimes we might find out something we already knew; other times, we may realize that our beliefs are hard to defend. Either way, by examining these ideas, we can do something good for everyone.

People who love food, like foodies and chefs, might think that thinking about what and how we eat can make eating more enjoyable. However, in history, discussions about food have often been less important than other philosophical topics. When philosophers talk about eating, they usually use it as a way to discuss something else, like gaining knowledge. Sometimes, conversations about food seem to be about food, but they often explore deeper ideas that are not directly related.

One interesting philosopher is Epicurus, who believed in seeking pleasure and avoiding pain in many areas of life. His name is now often connected with enjoying food and drink. You can see his name in restaurants, food shops, and recipe websites. These businesses likely hope to attract customers by linking their products to famous philosophers.

Food is also social and cultural. The food we eat comes from history and is shared with our communities. These communities help us find people to eat with and provide the means to grow and distribute food. We interact with food more than with any other product, making it a good topic for philosophical discussion.

Once food is ready, critics start to talk and write about it. But why do they have such a special role? One philosopher pointed out that tasting food is not a special skill; rather, good food critics are just better at describing flavors. This area has not been studied much, as most research on perception has focused on sight. 

Another important part of food is its beauty. We often talk about paintings or music being beautiful, but we rarely talk about the taste of food in the same way. Some philosophers believe that, because of modern cooking, food deserves to be discussed as art, like sculpture or poetry. However, food is eaten and gone after we enjoy it, unlike art that can last over time. So, it is not correct to think of food as a true art form.

There are also many ethical questions about food. We can ask what we should eat: organic, free-range, locally grown, vegetarian, or non-genetically modified foods? The answers often show our beliefs about what is right or wrong. Philosophers will always question why we choose certain foods, and discussing these issues is important.

Cooking at home and in restaurants is different. Home cooks have a special responsibility to their guests because of their personal relationships. In a home kitchen, everyone shares food and time together. In contrast, professional cooks have duties to their employers and the food itself. Their kitchens are not open to everyone, and their relationships are more like colleagues than friends.

A recent essay called "Diplomacy of the Dish" looks at how food and dining can help connect different cultures. This happens in two ways: first, we can learn to appreciate other cultures by enjoying their food; second, we can build friendships with people from other cultures by eating together. This practice has a long history in international relations. The essay includes many interesting examples and stories that make this part of food philosophy enjoyable for everyone.

Rob Daviau is from the US and he designs ‘legacy’ board games. He felt that the traditional board games he played as a child were not fun or challenging anymore. This made him think about how board games could change. Could they have a story? Could choices made in one game affect the next game? He changed a classic board game called Risk to create a new version called Risk Legacy. In this game, decisions made during play have a lasting effect. Players might have to tear up cards, mark the board, or open packets with new rules at important moments. The games are played over a set number of sessions, and players’ past actions become part of the game. Daviau said: “You could point to the board and say: ‘Right here! You did this!’”

Later, Daviau was asked to work on a legacy version of Pandemic, a very popular cooperative board game where players try to cure diseases. His next game was called SeaFall. While Pandemic Legacy was very well received, SeaFall was seen as a true test of the legacy format because it was the first game that did not follow an earlier version. Set in the age of sailing (16th to mid-19th century), players become sailors exploring a new world.

Designers of legacy board games must think about all possible player choices to keep the story from falling apart. To do this, they use play-testers to see how the games work. Jaime Barriga was a play-tester for SeaFall. He said, “It takes a lot of time. The first few games might be great, but then after a few more games, it can start to break. Then you have to go back and fix everything.”

Legacy board games were not expected to become very popular. When Daviau was developing the idea, he thought it would only appeal to a small group of people. He said, “I thought it was really different and pretty good, but it’s unexpected and breaks many rules. I thought I would be known as the guy who did this strange project.” However, many players, like Russell Chapman, loved the idea. He believes it is one of the biggest improvements in game design in years. He said, “It’s a new level of commitment, excitement, and intensity.”

Another fan, Ben Hogg, said that the fun of an unfolding adventure was more important than worrying about how long the game would last. He mentioned that people don’t usually watch the same movie twice in the cinema. “You’re buying into an experience,” he said. “It’s like the storytelling you find in video games.”

The legacy format is inspired not only by video games but also by popular TV shows. While in college, Daviau wanted to be a television writer, but he moved into advertising and then game design. Still, he loved telling stories. Matt Leacock, the creator of Pandemic, compared the legacy design process to writing a novel. He said, “You need to know how you want it to end and have a good idea of where to start, but you also need more than just an outline.”

Daviau feels proud of his work but is curious to see how others will use the idea. He thinks that soon gamers will be asking, “What’s new?” Colby Dauch, the studio manager for the publisher of SeaFall, is not so sure. He believes the legacy format has changed how people think about board games.

Not long ago, an octopus named Inky escaped from his tank at New Zealand’s National Aquarium. He crawled across the floor and squeezed into a small drain that led to the Pacific Ocean. This story was exciting and was shared a lot online. People enjoy stories like this because they like to think that animals are similar to us. Octopuses are especially interesting because they are very smart and look very different from humans. 

Octopuses can do amazing things like open jars, recognize faces, use coconut shells for protection, and even play games. Some scientists think that saying animals are like humans is not scientific. However, Dr. Frans de Waal, who studies animals like gorillas and chimpanzees, believes that not recognizing the human-like traits in animals is the real problem. He calls this "anthropodenial." 

Dr. de Waal has studied animal intelligence for many years. He found that, except for having a fully developed language, animals show many behaviors that we thought only humans could do. These behaviors include remembering the past and future, feeling empathy, and understanding what others want. This means animals are smarter than we usually think.

In the past, people believed that animals were smart enough to be put on trial for crimes. Even Charles Darwin, who changed how we see our place in the world, said that the difference between human and animal minds is just a matter of degree, not kind. 

In the twentieth century, many scientists started to see animals as simple machines that only respond to rewards and punishments. This view made people think less about animals’ inner lives. This change happened at the same time that humans were harming animal habitats and not caring for livestock properly. 

Dr. de Waal believes we are starting to understand animal intelligence better now. He says, “The times are changing.” He points out that we are learning more about animal intelligence, especially with the help of the internet. 

To test animal intelligence, scientists should consider the special skills of each species. For example, squirrels might not do well on human memory tests, but they can remember where they hide their nuts. In her book, The Soul of an Octopus, naturalist Sy Montgomery suggests that if an octopus tested human intelligence, it might judge us by how well we can change the colors of our skin. If we fail, it might think we are not very smart.

Dr. de Waal is not sure that Inky really found his way to the ocean. He thinks it is too hopeful to believe that Inky knew how to escape. However, he understands that stories like Inky’s help people appreciate animal intelligence. 

He once did an experiment to see if capuchin monkeys can feel envy. When some monkeys received cucumbers (which they like) and others received grapes (which they like even more), the monkeys with cucumbers got very upset when they saw the others getting grapes. This study was published in a scientific journal, but what really made people believe it was a short video of the experiment released ten years later. This shows how our minds work in unique ways. 

**Questions:**

1. What did Inky the octopus do at the aquarium?
2. Why do people enjoy stories about animals like Inky?
3. What are some things that octopuses can do that show their intelligence?
4. What does Dr. Frans de Waal think about how we view animal intelligence?
5. How did views on animal intelligence change in the twentieth century?
6. What example does Dr. de Waal give about how different animals have different skills?
7. What did Dr. de Waal find out about capuchin monkeys in his experiment?

Robotics, once just a part of science fiction, is now changing our world in a big way. Robots have been used in car making and factories for many years, but experts say we are about to see robots used in many more areas. They warn that many countries are not ready for this big change. 

Many people think that robots will take over most jobs done by humans in the next 50 years. However, about 80% of people believe their own jobs will still exist in the same way during that time. This shows that we feel safe about our jobs, but we might not be. Every industry will be affected by robots in the coming years. 

For example, an Australian company called Fastbrick Robotics has created a robot named Hadrian X that can lay 1,000 bricks in one hour. This job would take two human workers a whole day or more. Another example is a robot called Tally, made by a startup in San Francisco. Tally moves around supermarkets to check that products are in the right place and priced correctly, rather than cleaning the aisles.

Supporters of robots say that robots cannot fix or program themselves yet. This means there will be new jobs for skilled workers like technicians and programmers. However, some people worry that we should not forget the importance of human skills at work. They believe society is not ready for the changes that will come from using fewer human workers.

Dr. Jing Bing Zhang, an expert in robotics, studies how robots will change jobs in the future. His recent report says that in two years, almost one-third of robots will be smarter and able to work with other robots and humans safely. In three years, many big companies will have a chief robotics officer, and some governments will create laws about robots. In five years, salaries in the robotics field will rise by at least 60%, but many jobs will still be open because there are not enough skilled workers.

Zhang says that automation will affect lower-skilled workers, which is unfortunate. He believes these workers need to find ways to retrain themselves instead of waiting for the government to protect their jobs. He says that people cannot expect to do the same job for their whole lives anymore.

New technologies will also create new types of robots for consumers, like robots that can walk and live in our homes and interact with us in smart ways. This is a great chance for companies, but it also brings challenges, like the need for new rules to keep us safe and protect our privacy. 

With many jobs at risk and a global employment crisis coming, it is important to focus on education to prepare for the future with robots. Developed countries need more graduates in science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM) to stay competitive.

Text: George Mallory, a famous mountaineer, is said to have answered a reporter's question about why he wanted to climb Mount Everest by saying, "Because it’s there." This answer shows a common feeling: many people wonder why someone would want to do something so dangerous and seemingly pointless. Some may feel inspired by his answer to follow their own dreams, as it encourages people to face the unknown. However, the main point is that climbing can simply be about adventure and fun.

In 1967, Bolivian writer Tejada-Flores wrote an important essay called "Games that Climbers Play." He described seven different climbing activities, from playing on small rocks to climbing high mountains, each with its own rules. He believed that the way climbers approach a climb, like how much equipment they use, depends on the rules of that specific activity. Over the years, this idea has become popular in climbing discussions in the West, appearing in climbing magazines and conversations.

Many climbers love climbing because it gives them a sense of freedom. However, climbing can also feel very limiting. For example, being stuck in a tent during a storm is not what most people think of as freedom. This creates a contradiction in climbing. But some argue that having fewer choices can make a climber's life simpler, which can also feel like freedom.

When asked "Why climb?", US rock climber Joe Fitschen suggests a different question: "Why do people climb?" He believes that climbing is part of our nature; we are born to take on challenges and test our limits, even if it is risky. The joy we find in climbing is more about our biology than logical thinking.

US academic Brian Treanor also wrote about climbing, saying it helps develop important qualities like courage, humility, and respect for nature. He believes these qualities are especially important in today's world, which often avoids risks. Climbing can help us grow and live better lives outside of climbing.

Another idea is that climbers who do not depend on others or technology must be fully committed to succeed. Expert climbers Ebert and Robinson stirred some debate by saying that climbing alone is harder and riskier, so these achievements should be recognized more than those done with teams or with help like bottled oxygen at high altitudes. Some worry that this view might encourage climbers to take unnecessary risks.

We can also look at climbing from a different perspective. Many climbers talk about being "in the moment" or "going with the flow." The physical effort of climbing, the focus needed while climbing, and the intuitive problem-solving are all key parts of the experience. Some argue that climbing is similar to techniques in Zen philosophy, which helps people find peace of mind. This idea adds another layer to the question of why people are drawn to climbing.

For over sixty years, the pianist Alfred Brendel became a well-known figure in classical music. He was serious and thoughtful, focusing on important European piano works. He wrote and performed a lot, but he did not teach many students. People who knew him saw a fun side to him, but he rarely showed it during concerts. His life was a busy mix of studying, traveling, and performing.

About four or five years ago, a young boy named Kit Armstrong came to one of Brendel’s concerts and asked for lessons. At first, Brendel did not take this request seriously. He had very few students and did not see a reason to start teaching now. He remembered a famous pianist saying, “You don’t hire a mountain guide to teach a child how to walk.” However, he was impressed by Kit, who was about 14 years old. Brendel listened to him play and said, “He played very well and from memory. Then he gave me a CD of a recital he had done, and I thought, ‘I need to make time for him.’ His performance was amazing, leading you from the first note to the last. It is rare to find a musician with such understanding and skill.”

As Brendel steps back from the public eye, Kit is starting to become more known. Brendel is careful, worried that Kit might burn out too quickly. Now 19, Kit is always busy, learning new languages, studying math, writing computer code, or playing tennis, all while his mother watches over him. He also composes music. Brendel says, “This is very important. Learning to read music is easier when you try to write your own. I noticed that Kit has an incredible memory and can read music very well. More importantly, he listens to his own playing and understands what I explain. When I tell him something to do in a piece, he can do it everywhere in that piece.”

Brendel becomes serious and says, “I don’t want to raise expectations. I get upset when newspapers do this. One article called him the future great pianist of the 21st century, which is not good. It can cause problems. Like many talented young players, he can play some pieces very well, but others need more time and practice. It would be unfair for a critic to expect perfection.”

Now at 80 years old, Brendel is more relaxed in his life after performing. He explains, “When I was young, I didn’t want to be famous quickly, but I wanted to achieve certain things by the age of 50. When I turned 50, I felt I had done most of those things, but I still wanted to do more, so I continued. Even though I don’t have the same physical strength now, I still have many ideas in my mind and pieces I have never played. I don’t perform now, but I enjoy this new phase of my career.”

Text: "When I was a child, I thought gardens were beautiful places. My grandad’s garden was by a river and sloped down to the water. You couldn’t reach the river, but you could hear the water and the birds in the trees. I thought all gardens were like this – peaceful and quiet. Grandad’s garden was simple. He didn’t have a fancy greenhouse like some neighbors. Their greenhouses were made from old window frames, with plastic covering broken glass. 

At home, my father was often quiet. He had a sense of humor and liked to say funny phrases, like ‘It’s immaterial to me.’ He could have said ‘I don’t mind,’ but he preferred the word ‘immaterial.’ Deep down, he might have felt disappointed with his life. He left school without qualifications and became a plumber, which he didn’t love. He wasn’t very ambitious, although he and my mother once thought about moving to Canada, but it didn’t happen. 

My father was good at fixing things around the house. He could build bookshelves or cupboards very well. My parents only moved house once, but my mother liked to change the furniture often. Just when you got used to one chair, another would appear. The biggest change was when a piano came into the house. I wanted to like it, but it made me nervous. I liked the two brass candlesticks on it, but my mother said they were too fancy, and they disappeared while I was at school. I was never allowed to play the piano; my sister took lessons instead. When I asked my mother why I couldn’t play, she simply said, ‘You’d never have practiced.’

Of the three places to explore – moors, woods, or river – I always chose the river. I could imagine another world there. With a fishing net over my shoulder, I would walk along the riverbank in my old sandals, looking for a good spot to take them off. I would leave my sandals with my picnic and carefully look for fish in the water to catch. After some failed attempts to keep the fish alive in the backyard, I returned them to the river.

I wanted to leave school as soon as I could, but it seemed impossible until one day my father said, ‘There’s a job for an apprentice gardener in the Parks Department. I thought you might be interested.’ In that moment, my dad surprised me. He might have preferred if I became a carpenter, but I like to think he saw my interest in gardening. Even though he didn’t like gardening himself, he had watched me enjoy it and noticed my passion for plants and flowers."

**Simplified Text:**

Lawrence MacEwen is crouching down on his Scottish island, the Isle of Muck. I am doing the same. A strong wind from the Atlantic is trying to blow us away, over the steep cliff at our feet and into the ocean below. Then, MacEwen’s sheepdog, Tie, comes close, and his owner gently pets him. The strong wind cannot make MacEwen uncomfortable here on his island, where he feels at home. 

MacEwen is showing me around his neighborhood. He points to the north and shouts, “That island is Eigg. The one to the west is the Isle of Rum. It gets twice as much rain as we do.” I see dark clouds pouring rain on Rum’s big mountains. “Just beyond Rum is the island of Soay.” 

Suddenly, MacEwen says, “I have sheep to move,” as rain starts to come our way. We walk down the slopes. As we walk, he tells me about the island: Volcanic Muck is three kilometers long and one and a half kilometers wide; its geese eat a lot of grass; and the MacEwen family has lived here for 3000 years. 

While herding the sheep, Tie, the sheepdog, is not doing a good job. “Away to me, Tie. Away to me,” means the dog should go to the right. Instead, he goes straight through the flock, causing confusion. “Tie,” MacEwen says sadly. “That will never do.” The dog looks ashamed. 

The Isle of Muck is mostly run by the MacEwen family. Lawrence works the farm with his wife, Jenny; their son Colin manages the island cottages; and their daughter Mary runs the island hotel, Port Mor, with her husband, Toby. Mary and Toby enjoy that their two boys can explore the island and sail small boats in the summer. “They go out the door and come back only when they are hungry.” 

But life on the island has some challenges. For example, electricity is only available sometimes. On my first evening, I wait for the lights to turn on. The next morning, I see Mary preparing breakfast with a flashlight. I also have to deal with no mobile phone service. “There is phone reception on the hill,” Mary tells me. “Most people last a couple of days, then just put the phone away.” So I do the same. 

Everything on Muck seems surprising. The boat today brings some groceries and three musicians, who get off the boat with their instruments. Their concert in the island’s tearoom is a big success, with the islanders tapping their feet to the music. 

That night, sitting by a warm fire while it rains outside, Lawrence MacEwen tells me how he met his wife, Jenny. “Her father saw a small farm on the isle of Soay in a newspaper and bought it without looking at it. He had never been to Scotland. Jenny was sent to manage it.” Did Jenny know how to run a farm? “She had good typing skills.” 

I go to bed listening to the rain and wake up to more rain. But I eat well, as almost all my food comes from the island. Mary sends me to fisherman Sandy Mathers for fresh fish. I carry it back through the village and give it to Mary at the kitchen door. By 7 pm, our fish is on the table, and it is delicious. 

The next morning, I worry about my ferry ride to the next island. Many ferries had been canceled in the last two months because of high waves. If my ferry does not come, I would be stuck on Muck for two more days. And secretly, I wish for that to happen, phone or no phone.

Text: 'The game design industry was once mostly made up of computer scientists and self-taught individuals. It did not offer many ways for people to enter the field. Many people thought of video games as just a hobby for young fans, but now the industry is taken seriously. This change may surprise some, but experts in the field are not surprised. However, getting into the industry is still not easy. Video game spin-offs that come out quickly after a new movie need many team members and a lot of skill and hard work. Like many industries, it can be hard to get in, but it is growing. 

Jim Donelly, a spokesperson for an online games magazine, says, "It is very difficult to make progress in big companies or to influence major games. But the truth is, the industry needs game designers more than ever. Not just the top-level directors who manage a whole game, but also the lower-level designers who create systems and individual parts of the game." 

So, how can you enter this competitive industry? Many companies prefer candidates with a degree in computer science, but Jim has a different opinion. "There is only one way: make games. The tools are available. You won’t get a job if you haven’t created something, and you won’t succeed on your own if you are not making things. Game design is more than just a job; it is a way of life. Like any creative work, it must be done to be real."

Another expert, John Field, sees other options. "While just doing it is important, it is more complicated than that. Many people want to work in games, but few meet the industry’s requirements today. Even fewer have the creative talent, technical skills, vision, and business sense to really help the industry grow." 

Can you succeed on your own? "Maybe, but it is quite difficult," says John. "A good postgraduate course in games can help and provide support and guidance for a year or two. Most game designers start as programmers or artists and work their way up. They are interested in all types of entertainment and have a strong interest in the arts and modern culture. They may have worked for a few years after graduation but have realized that games are their passion. They are not just fans; they are excited about the future of games and understand the growing variety in the field. 

Finally, making connections is important. This is often forgotten, but to succeed in games, as in many other areas, you need to network." The old image of a young boy playing video games has changed. Now, video games are seen as a serious medium that attracts many people. Families often play together on interactive consoles, and smartphones offer many new games through apps and social media. John believes there is a lot of room for growth. "Games have become popular for larger audiences. They are also a great way to learn, and I see this area as full of new possibilities and opportunities."

Text: "Since I was a child, I have always wanted to play football. My dad encouraged me to play, but he never forced me. I am thankful for that. I had a friend who came to the park with us, but his dad was very strict. He always said, ‘You can’t do this, you can’t do that.’ My friend could have been a good player, but he stopped wanting to play and has not played football since. I am glad that did not happen to me, but I know things could have been different. When I score a great goal from far away, people often say it is just luck, but it is not. I have practiced taking long shots since I was a kid. You can only score amazing goals by practicing. The best players in the world have natural talent, but they also practice for many years. Sometimes young players crash into each other, but I learned the right techniques. When I teach kids, I always tell them to enjoy learning new skills. I played many sports at school, like rounders, baseball, athletics, and basketball. I know now that a good education is important, but football was all I thought about back then. The teachers were doing a good job, but I did not notice it at the time. I do not want my son to be like that. We are already trying to read him books, even though he is too young to sit still for long. I hope that he just wants to kick the books around and not that he takes after me in that way. 

At the start of my professional football career, the manager made big sacrifices so that some younger players could play for the first team, but he never made a big deal about it. He did not call us together and say, ‘This is your big chance,’ but we all knew we had to prove ourselves. I scored in the first game of the season, but we lost. A famous TV presenter said, ‘You can’t win anything with kids.’ This made us realize how much we had to work. We had some doubts, but we believed in ourselves as a team. I depend a lot on my close friends and family. However, having a lot of money can sometimes cause problems. For example, people say to me, ‘I can’t believe you let your mother keep working.’ I have helped my parents with money. I paid off their house loan and bought them a car last Christmas. My family are strong people, and I think they would be upset if they thought they should be paid by me. My mum does not earn much as a hairdresser, but she loves her job. On the other hand, I enjoy using my money to help the people around me. I have a lot of money, but not as much as people think, and it does not solve all my problems. After I stop playing, I want to take a year off or even longer to do things I have not been able to do. I want to go skiing the day after I stop playing. I cannot do that now because if I break a leg while skiing and cannot play football again, I would not be insured."

Text: 'Sam Carter was the reason we lived at Reef Point. He was my father’s agent in Los Angeles. My father was having a hard time writing there, so Sam offered to help us find a cheap place to live. The beach was quiet during the summer because of the sea fogs. Reef Point did not get many visitors. The road was not very nice, and a better resort, La Carmella, was nearby. Most people chose to stay there instead. Only those who were broke or loved surfing would come to Reef Point. But now, with the hot weather, many people were at the beach. After being alone for months, we were now surrounded by people and activities. My father was busy every day trying to finish a script, and he was very stressed. I often went to the beach with a book and my dog, Rusty. When we first moved to Reef Point, we didn’t have a dog, but Rusty started to follow me. I tried to send him away, but he kept coming back. One morning, I felt sorry for him and gave him some water. My father threw a boot at him, but he didn’t really want to hurt him. Rusty knew this and came closer. I asked my father, ‘Who does he belong to?’ My father replied, ‘He thinks we belong to him.’ Rusty loved the beach and liked to dig things up and bring them to me. Sometimes he found things that didn’t belong to him, like a new sneaker or a beach towel, and I had to return them. He also loved to swim and always wanted to join me, even though I could swim faster. That day, my father had gone to Los Angeles to deliver his script, and Rusty and I spent the afternoon playing in the sea. As the sun began to set, it got cooler, and we watched the surfers. They had been surfing all day and didn’t seem to get tired. One surfer caught my attention. She was very good and made the others look clumsy. When she finished, she came over to me and said, ‘Why didn’t you join us?’ I replied, ‘I don’t have a surfboard.’ She said, ‘You could get one.’ I answered, ‘I don’t have any money.’ Then she asked, ‘You’re British, right? Are you visiting?’ I said, ‘No, I live here.’ She asked, ‘Is your father American?’ I replied, ‘No, he came here to write a film script based on a novel he wrote.’ She seemed surprised and asked, ‘What’s his name?’ I said, ‘Rufus Marsh.’ She then said, ‘You mean, Tall as the Morning?’ I nodded. She looked at me with interest, and I realized that people were friendly but only showed interest when I mentioned my father’s book.'

Text: 

"What have I done?" Violet Hetherington asked herself. She was standing in a long line at the dock in Southampton. The line was spilling out of the building marked ‘Departures’ as people waited to board the Queen Caroline. "It’s best to get to the docks late," her friend Annie had told her. "If you get there too early, you can get bored waiting." Annie, who was married to a diplomat and traveled a lot, usually gave good advice. But this time, she was wrong. 

After a while, an announcement came over the loudspeakers: there was a problem with the computer system. The mood among the waiting passengers became worse. Some tried to be patient, and a few even tried to be cheerful, but most people were unhappy. They had paid a lot of money for this trip, and they wanted it to be special. Violet felt like leaving. She checked her bag for her phone and realized it was missing. This was more annoying than the long wait. It made her feel that going on a cruise was a mistake. 

Now, she couldn’t call the taxi company to see if she left her phone in the taxi because all her numbers were in her phone. This was the mistake her older son Harry always warned her about. Behind her in the line, there was a friendly-looking couple. "I’m sorry, but I think I left my mobile phone behind. Could I borrow yours to make a call?" Violet asked. She called Harry using the couple’s phone and left a message for him to ask their neighbor, Kristina, to check if her phone was at home. If it wasn’t there, she would be in trouble because she had no other way to find the numbers she needed in New York. Part of her thought, "Thank goodness," but she didn’t tell Harry this. 

Harry thought he was more experienced than his mother. Daniel, her younger son, was more understanding of her mistakes, but that was because he made them too. Dan might forget to give the message to Kristina. Eventually, the line started to move, and Violet went to a window where she gave her travel documents and got ready to board. 

Her heart sank when she entered the ship’s lobby, which looked like a fancy hotel that was trying too hard. There were shiny fake wood panels, big chandeliers, shiny brass, and carpets that looked like those in airports. Violet followed the signs to the ‘Elevators,’ which were full of mirrors and crowded with tired passengers. They might have preferred not to see their reflections. Violet was pressed against the side of the lift as it went up, stopping at each floor to let people out. Finally, on the twelfth floor, she stepped out and felt free. Thankfully, her room had the balcony she had asked for. She had been worried about what to say if it didn’t. Ignoring Annie’s advice to wait for a better deal, she had decided to pay the highest price she could afford to make sure she had a good view of the sea.

Text: 

When John Maloof bought a box of old photo negatives at an auction, he did not know he was starting to uncover the mystery of Vivian Maier. Maloof was looking for pictures to use in a book about the Portage Park neighborhood in Chicago, USA. Instead, he found 30,000 images taken by Maier, a street photographer with a talent for capturing interesting moments. Since then, Maloof has collected many items related to Maier’s life and work. In his home attic, he has her cameras, 2,000 rolls of film, 3,000 prints, and 100,000 negatives, along with many 8mm movies and audiotapes. 

One morning, Maloof looked around at everything he had. He felt he was close to discovering something special, and it happened by chance. “When I bought all this, I had no idea what it was,” Maloof said. “I could have easily sold it all to someone else.” For a while, Maloof and his friend Anthony Rydzon have been trying to learn more about Maier’s life. They spoke to local families who had hired her as a nanny and talked to people at the shop where she developed her film. 

Maier was born in 1926 in New York and spent much of her childhood in France. In 1951, she returned to New York and in 1956 moved to Chicago to work as a nanny. Maier was a private person and had a unique style. She often wore large coats, wide-brimmed hats, and sturdy shoes. “On her day off, she would have her camera around her neck and we wouldn’t see her again until late at night,” said Maren Baylaender, whose husband employed Maier to care for his daughter. “I remember her as a private person but she had strong opinions about movies and politics.” 

Maier knew a lot about theater and movies. Although she was not very social, she liked to walk the streets with her camera and talk to people, some of whom she interviewed on audiotape. She seemed to be very dedicated to her “second job” of documenting the world around her. “She was a true artist and followed her dreams,” said Rydzon. “She didn’t let anything stop her.” 

Maier’s work is a pure form of art; she did not create it for money. Her images often show women, children, the elderly, the poor, and abstract scenes. “What is interesting about Vivian is that she has so many fascinating pictures,” said photography expert Larry Silverman. He sees influences from other photographers in her work and wonders if she developed her own style. “Was Vivian very skilled or did she take ideas from those before her?” 

Maloof often thinks about whether he will ever go through all the negatives, which he keeps in three tall, fireproof file cabinets. The funny thing is he had no real interest in photography until he found Maier’s work. Inspired by her architectural photos, Maloof started taking his own pictures. “As I learned more about photography and looked back at her work, I realized that the cityscapes were not what mattered to her. It’s the people, the street scenes, and the overall composition,” he said. “There was so much more to this work than I thought, and I realized I was sitting on something more important than I ever imagined. Now our goal is to share her name and get Vivian Maier into the history books.”

When people say a novel is ambitious, they often mean it might not succeed. But this is not the case with Eleanor Catton’s book, *The Luminaries*. I interviewed her in the UK when her book was very popular, and she seemed calm, especially for someone in her twenties. She had just arrived from Germany and was going back to New Zealand the next day. She shared a story about being stopped at passport control and asked to prove she was a writer. She pressed her novel against the glass. The official looked at it and asked, “What’s it about?” This is not an easy question for an author.

*The Luminaries* takes place in New Zealand during the 1860s. A series of crimes have happened, and a group of 12 men has come together to solve them. The story becomes very complex. Catton said she wanted to write a murder mystery, not a historical novel, but she found that the past gave her more chances for complications and misunderstandings for her characters. The book is more than 800 pages long because she wanted to give each of the 20 main characters a good chance to shine.

When I asked her how it feels to be so successful at a young age, she replied that it feels nice to come from a small country because everyone feels part of the success. She said, “There’s a very familial feeling at home; I got a lot of back pats from other people’s grandmas.” She also mentioned that it annoys her when people think her book is not serious.

Catton explained that she wanted to write the book in the shape of a spiral, where each part is half the length of the one before it. The story speeds up as it goes along. I asked if it matters whether readers notice these patterns. She said she wanted to create a book with patterns that didn’t matter, but if readers cared, they could find them.

Even with its unique structure, *The Luminaries* is still an exciting murder mystery with a gripping plot. Surprisingly, Catton said she didn’t plan the story in advance. “I would try to write myself into a corner and then see how creative I could be to get out of that situation,” she said. One of her goals was to make the book enjoyable for readers.

We also talked about her love for television dramas. I asked if she would be interested in writing for TV. She replied, “That could be pretty cool.” She spoke with excitement and laughed softly. She lights up when discussing her writing and New Zealand. “I notice when I come to Britain how much my imagination changes just by being in a different place. I understand why writers leave New Zealand for busy cities to be around more people.” But for now, New Zealand will still be her home. I hope it gives her the inspiration she needs for many more novels.

When Jonny Kinkead was a boy, he liked to make things in his dad’s garage and play the guitar. For the last forty years, he has been building acoustic guitars by hand.
