Jonny says, “I still love the guitar. It amazes me that you can make a beautiful sound just by putting two pieces of wood together. Different types of wood make different sounds, and that still surprises me.”

Jonny learned to play his brother’s guitar when he was eleven. At sixteen, he wanted to learn the bass guitar. He says, “Some people would get a job to save money for one, but I thought if I wanted something, I should make it myself. I studied guitars to understand how different shapes and types of wood change the sound.”

The bass guitar was the first instrument Jonny built himself, but he and his brothers had been making model boats and planes for a long time. Their father taught them how to use tools like saws and chisels. Jonny also repaired instruments for his friends. His bass guitar turned out well, but he didn’t think about making guitars as a career at that time. He was also interested in painting and sculpture. After finishing school, he decided to study architecture at university because it involved design, which he liked. However, halfway through the course, he dropped out because he felt it wasn’t right for him. He realized that building guitars was a type of sculpture that involved creating sound, and he thought it would be a better career than pure art because people actually use the things he makes.

Since then, Jonny has made guitars for a living. For the first ten years, he also cleaned windows part-time to earn extra money. At first, he sold his guitars for just the cost of materials, but as he became known as a good guitar-maker, he could charge more. Even now, almost forty years later, Jonny says he is “still scratching a living.” He can only make about ten guitars a year, which limits his income.

In the beginning, he worked hard to get known. He went to music festivals on weekends to let musicians try his guitars and talk about him. He also had to learn how to price his instruments because he didn’t think about money much. Jonny believes it is easier for new guitar-makers in the UK today. He says, “When I started, many people thought only American-made acoustic guitars were good. UK-made guitars were not seen as real, even though we have always had good courses for making instruments. Now, our hand-made guitars have a good reputation.”

Jonny thinks new instrument-makers should take courses to learn valuable skills. However, he also believes that learning by trying and making mistakes is important. He says, “You should look at other instruments, see what works and what doesn’t, and try different things. If you make the back of a guitar too thin or too thick, it won’t sound good. If you learn from someone else, you might only learn one way, but if you teach yourself, like I did, you learn everything.”

Text: 

When we talk about English conversation, we often start with the weather. This is a common tradition, and many writers mention the famous saying by Dr. Johnson, an 18th-century writer, who said, "When two Englishmen meet, their first talk is of the weather." This saying is still true today, just like it was over two hundred years ago. However, many people stop here or try to explain why the English are so interested in the weather, but they often fail. They think that when we talk about the weather, we are really interested in it. 

For example, the American writer Bill Bryson says that English weather is not interesting at all. He points out that in England, we do not have exciting weather events like tornadoes or big storms that happen in other places. On the other hand, the English broadcaster Jeremy Paxman disagrees with Bryson. He believes that English weather is interesting because it is always changing. He says that even if we do not have tropical storms, living near the ocean means we can never be sure what the weather will be like.

I believe that both Bryson and Paxman miss the main point. Our conversations about the weather are not really about the weather itself. Instead, talking about the weather is a way for English people to connect with each other. For example, when someone says, "Nice day, isn’t it?" or "Ooh, isn’t it cold?" they are not really asking about the weather. These phrases are just ways to start a conversation or fill a pause. 

Talking about the weather is like a form of social bonding, similar to how monkeys groom each other. There are specific situations where we use weather talk. Some people think that English people talk about the weather all the time, but that is not true. We usually use weather talk in three situations: as a greeting, to start a conversation, or when there is a pause in the conversation. 

Because of this, it may seem like we talk about the weather a lot. An English conversation might start with a weather greeting, then move to more weather talk, and return to it when there is a silence. This is why people from other countries, and even some English people, think that we are obsessed with the weather.

Text: Alice Leader was standing in front of Hadrian’s Wall in Britain. She was trying to explain to her class of 12- and 13-year-olds how amazing it was that the Romans built something 120 km long and 5 meters high about 1900 years ago. The students were interested in this trip instead of going to Spain, Greece, or France. However, they wanted to know why the wall was built, and Alice felt her answers were not good enough. She could not find a suitable historical novel to help her explain life at the Wall during Roman times, so she decided to write one herself. After teaching for 31 years, Alice started her new career as a writer in 2001. 

Alice felt that writing was a big change for her. She said, “Teaching is like acting; it’s a performance every day and very tiring. Writing is exciting and a bit scary, but it is not so exhausting. My former teaching colleagues envy me because I still connect with children through my stories.” Alice wants her novels to fill a gap in children’s fiction today. She noticed that many books for teenagers focus on negative experiences or are completely fantasy, like Harry Potter. She wants her books to be different.

Alice always taught English and History together, using stories like the Tale of Troy to make lessons interesting. She loves to see when a child goes from being bored to being interested. “I enjoy having bored children because it challenges me to make them engaged,” she said. She sees her writing as a way to continue teaching. 

Alice was inspired to write her first novel because she saw a need for it, but she also felt a change coming as her two sons were leaving home. Her head teacher suggested she take a creative writing course, which surprised her. “I had been teaching for 25 years, and I didn’t want to spend my summer on a course I didn’t think I needed.” Before she could join the course, she had to send in her best piece of writing, which she only learned a few days before the deadline. “I sat down and quickly created a story about a Roman couple and their baby-to-be.” After three hours and 30 pages, she sent it in and was accepted.

During the course, other students reviewed her work and encouraged her to publish it. With only 8,000 report cards to show her writing skills, she asked her head teacher for a year off to write her first novel. Alice’s husband, Zachary Leader, is a critic and editor, and his help was very important for her writing. Alice said, “My mother-in-law thinks we are rival authors, but I believe we help each other. He works with what I write – he reads a chapter and changes the sentences, and if something doesn’t work, he suggests new words. I tend to add more scenes. That’s the difference between a fiction writer and an editor.”

**Simplified Text:**

To raise money for charity, a newspaper and a TV company asked brothers Jonny and Alistair Brownlee, who are champion triathletes, to join a special race. This race would have Jonny in a car and Alistair on a mountain bike, racing against each other in the beautiful and hilly Yorkshire Dales in northern England. They would race to the same finish line. Jonny was excited and said, “I’ve never done anything like this before! These roads have beautiful views, and it’s very cold, so I can stay warm in the car.” Alistair, the younger brother, was also eager but dressed in warm cycling clothes. He joked, “I’ve seen Jonny drive before, so I’m not sure he will make it. I might stop for a cup of tea halfway!”

The race started at Semerwater lake in Wensleydale and would finish at Fleet Moss, which is the highest road in Yorkshire, about 350 meters up. This would be easy for the car, but Alistair had to climb a steep hill at the beginning. They quickly shook hands and started the race. Alistair rode away on his bike, while Jonny got into his car and drove off. The question was, who would reach the finish line first?

Jonny’s confidence quickly dropped when he faced a big problem. Just 15 seconds into his drive, a giant tractor came onto the road. He complained to the cameraman, “If Alistair beats me, it’s because of this farmer!” After getting past the tractor, Jonny continued driving. Meanwhile, Alistair was having a hard time with the steep hill. He had to get off his bike and carry it up the hill, while sheep watched him curiously. Finally, he reached the top and was ready to go faster.

In the car, Jonny faced another problem. The roads in Yorkshire are old and narrow. He had to drive slowly around a tight corner and through a small stream on the road. Once he got past the last village, he could drive straight to the finish line. Neither brother knew how close they were to each other. Jonny sped up as he approached Fleet Moss, while Alistair was racing across his last field and back onto the road.

As Alistair reached the finish line, he suddenly stopped and asked the crowd, “Is he here?” When they said no, he raised his arms in celebration and shouted, “Yes!” A few minutes later, Jonny arrived in his car and got out. “Well done,” he said, feeling disappointed. “I’m gutted.” 

**Questions:**

1. What was the purpose of the race?
2. Who was in the car and who was on the bike?
3. Where did the race start and where did it finish?
4. What problem did Jonny face while driving?
5. How did Alistair feel when he reached the finish line?

Text: 'The silence is what you notice when you play on Centre Court at Wimbledon. You bounce the ball quietly on the soft grass; you toss it up to serve; you hit it and hear the echo of your shot. The trimmed grass, the history, the old stadium, the players in white, and the respectful crowds all make you feel separate from the outside world. The quiet of Centre Court helps my game. What I find hardest in a tennis match is to focus only on the game and the point I am playing. The silence is broken by noise when a point ends: applause, cheers, and people shouting your name. I hear them, but it feels far away. I don’t think about the fifteen thousand people watching me, or the millions watching around the world as I play Roger Federer in the 2008 Wimbledon final – the biggest match of my life. I had always dreamed of playing at Wimbledon. My uncle Toni, my coach, taught me from a young age that this was the biggest tournament. By the time I was 14, I was sharing with my friends that I would play there one day and win. Before 2008, I had played and lost to Federer twice – in the final the year before and the year before that. The loss in 2006 was not so hard. I was just happy to be there at twenty years old. Federer beat me easily, but my loss in 2007 was very hard. I knew I could have done better; it was not my skill that failed me, but my mind. I cried for half an hour in the dressing room after that loss. Losing always hurts, but it hurts more when you have a chance and lose it. Toni, my tough coach, usually does not comfort me, even when I win. But that time, he told me there was no reason to cry and that there would be more Wimbledons and finals. I told him he didn’t understand; I thought it was my last chance to win. I know how short a professional athlete's career is, and I want to make the most of it. Every moment counts, but some moments are more important than others, and I had let a big one slip away in 2007. There was nothing Toni could do to help me feel better. But he was right in the end. Another chance came in 2008, just one year later. I was confident I had learned from my defeat; this time, my mind would be strong. The best sign that I was ready was that I believed I would win. The night before the final, at dinner with family and friends, we did not talk about the match. I didn’t tell them not to, but they understood that I was already thinking about the match in my mind. From then until the match started, that space in my mind was mine alone.'

Text: 'In early April 1957, a young and hopeful Englishwoman arrived in Africa. In her first letter home, she wrote, “I am living in the Africa I have always wanted.” Her name was Jane Goodall, and she would spend most of her life in Africa. She became known as a citizen, journalist, scientist, activist, and environmentalist. In 1963, the National Geographic Society in Britain helped make Jane Goodall famous by publishing articles and making television documentaries about her research on chimpanzees. Her fame grew with her own writing, including popular children’s books and the 1971 bestseller In the Shadow of Man, which has been translated into 47 languages and is still available today. Jane Goodall is one of the most celebrated female scientists of the 20th century, second only to Marie Curie. However, her fame sometimes overshadows her real achievements. Many articles and interviews tell her life story, but they often focus on her personal life rather than her work. She has been seen as a girl seeking adventure, a privileged woman who wanted to be with wild animals, and a strong woman in a man’s world. These images do not fully show what she has accomplished. 

Jane Goodall should be recognized as a leading scientist in her field because of her research, the success of her students, and the large amount of data she collected over her forty-year study. She helped us understand the social and emotional lives of chimpanzees. Before her work, people thought wild chimpanzees were very dangerous, and they misunderstood the risks involved. No one knew that chimpanzees ate meat or that they used tools, like humans do. We also did not realize that chimpanzees have emotions similar to ours or that their social lives are much like ours. Goodall discovered that chimpanzee communities in Africa have their own unique cultural traditions. Her book, The Chimpanzees of Gombe (1986), is the most important work in this field and is the first encyclopedia on chimpanzee research. Her long study of wild chimpanzees in Gombe State, Nigeria, is considered one of the great scientific achievements of the Western world. Jane Goodall changed how we study animals, and because chimpanzees are our closest relatives, she also changed how we think about ourselves.

Even as a child, there were signs of the person Jane Goodall would become. One clear sign happened in the autumn of 1939 when she was just five years old. One day, Jane disappeared, and her family called the police to help find her. After a long search, she came back alone, with straw in her hair and clothes. Her mother asked, “Where have you been?” Jane explained that she wanted to know how hens lay eggs. To find out, she crawled into a henhouse, hid in the straw, and stayed very still for five hours until a hen laid an egg. This moment can be seen as the start of her journey to becoming a biologist.'

Text: 

In our first conversation, Shirley Ford talks to me using the voice of a funny 8-year-old boy, a tired mother, an amusing old Scottish woman, and a very fast-talking alien. Her voices are familiar to people who watch children’s TV and cartoons. “I just did a voiceover about back injuries,” she says. “I had to learn how to say many medical terms quickly.” 

Shirley explains what it takes to do voiceovers. “Many actors think they can do funny voices, and some really can,” she says. “But it’s more than that. You have to make the script exciting for an audience that can’t see you. Many famous actors want to do voiceover work, but they often don’t get the parts because they are used to acting with their whole bodies.”

After school, Shirley took a drama course, hoping for a regular acting career. During the course, she sometimes sang jingles for TV ads. “One day,” she says, “the man who ran the recording studio suggested I try out for the voice of a rabbit in a cartoon. It seemed silly – I didn’t study drama to play rabbits – but I tried it for fun and, surprisingly, got a big part.” Shirley discovered she could do voices and thought voiceover work might be a good path for her. “Things just happened for me,” she says. “In my second film, I was lucky to play the main character, her brother, and her mother.”

Adult female actors often provide the voices for small boys and girls because their voices are lighter than male actors. Hiring child performers is complicated, and production companies prefer to avoid the long process. Shirley has learned to create different sounds and collects new voices by watching children’s TV. 

Cartoons are the best part of her job, which also includes educational videos and vacuum cleaner ads. “Those are tough because you have to sound excited about something you don’t care about, but my experience helps,” she says. “I’ve learned that smiling while you talk makes your voice sound happy.” When she works on animation, it feels like a holiday because interacting with other actors is enjoyable.

The competition for voiceover work is strong, and having a good showreel – a recording that shows what you can do – is very important. “It’s worth investing in a strong showreel,” Shirley says. “There are agencies that help voiceover artists create them.” She believes she has reached the top of her profession through hard work as much as talent. “Whether it’s making your showreel or practicing your voices, it’s all about setting goals and not giving up.”

For anyone thinking about a career in voiceovers, Shirley suggests attending special workshops that cover all types of voiceover work. She also thinks it’s important to love human sound, saying she is obsessed with voices and becomes the characters she plays. “If I’ve been in the studio doing a specific American voice, it can take over me, and I’ll speak like that for hours or even days,” she says. “My children have grown up hearing their mom talk in many different voices.”

Text: 'People often ask me how I became a cartoonist. This is understandable because cartooning is a job many kids dream about, like being a race car driver. However, most people give up these dreams and think about more practical jobs, like being a tax lawyer or making car parts. The idea that you can make a living by drawing simple pictures, like the doodles in school notebooks, seems silly. But some people do it. 

Not everyone becomes a cartoonist in the same way, but most have wanted to do it for a long time. For me, I had a typical childhood for a cartoonist. I loved comic strips, contributed to school publications, and was known as ‘the kid who draws.’ I studied graphic design in college and, after graduating, I showed my illustrations to different companies. I was lucky to find someone at a newspaper who needed political cartoons about local issues. I created a few ideas, and they bought them. In a few months, I was making enough money to support myself.

You don’t need much to become a cartoonist. You don’t need a university degree, a lot of money, or even to be a great artist. You just need your brain, your hand, and something to draw with. But if it were that easy, there would be many more cartoonists. The skills needed to be a cartoonist are not hard to learn, but it is still a tough job. You should only try to be a cartoonist if you feel you cannot do anything else. It is much easier to get a regular job that pays the bills and gives you time for family, home repairs, and hobbies.

The more skills you have, the better chance you have of making a living with your art. I have done political cartoons, comic strips, and comic books. I have also been a writer, a caricaturist, and sometimes a designer. I take on all kinds of work because you can learn a lot, even from jobs you don’t really want to do. It helps to be smart, well-read, and curious about the world.

What about the business side of being a cartoonist? There was a time when many cartoonists could find regular jobs with different newspapers and magazines. But those days are fading. Now, cartooning is often a business where you have to create and sell your work. The more comfortable you are with selling, the better you will do. I have seen cartoonists with average drawing skills but great business skills do much better than those who are very talented but lack business sense.

It surprises me how often I meet people who have never sold a cartoon and are afraid someone will steal their ideas. Some are so worried that they won’t even let others see their work! Legally, to protect your work, you just need to draw a small ‘c’ for ‘copyright,’ put a circle around it, and write your name and the date next to it. But honestly, it is more likely that no one will be interested in your work. If someone does steal a cartoon and it becomes popular online, it is not a disaster – it can actually be a lucky break!'

**Simplified Text:**

Twenty years ago, I was moving to a new house and cleaning out my things. I decided to throw away an electric guitar that my dad had given me for my 16th birthday. It was a nice, black guitar from Japan. I usually hate getting rid of things, so why did I want to throw this away? I took it to the dump and was about to put it on a pile of trash when a young man came up to me, looking confused. “You’re not going to throw that away, are you?” he asked. I said I was, and I started to feel regret. He asked if he could have it, and I said “Yes.” After that, I felt sad about what I had done.

A few months ago, I opened an email that changed my life. I remembered a story about a man who lost his wedding ring in the ocean. Ten years later, he found it in a fish he was eating. That’s how I felt when I read an email from someone I didn’t know, a guitar dealer named Keith Rushton. He said, “I’ve got your electric guitar.” It had been sold many times since the young man at the dump took it. Keith found my name and address on a label on the guitar. He used my name to find me online and contacted me through the newspaper I work for. He offered to sell it back to me. I was so happy I almost cried. I would have given him anything, but his price was fair. I had forgotten that my dad always put name labels on my things, including my guitar. My dad would have laughed at this strange story!

My parents wanted me to learn classical guitar because it was popular in the 1970s. I loved the sound of it; it was calming and gentle. Unlike the violin, it didn’t sound bad when a beginner played it. But I didn’t make much progress, so I switched to the electric guitar and played easier songs. This was also the time of punk music, when people who couldn’t play well could still be rock stars.

When I took my old guitar out of the box that Keith sent me, I remembered my birthday in 1978 when my parents gave it to me. Holding it again felt smooth and smaller than I remembered. I sat down to play, but then I wanted to stand up and put a strap over my shoulder because electric guitars are played that way. My fingers knew what to do. I couldn’t draw the chords, but my hands just moved. My fingers felt the special pain of pressing down the strings to play a chord. The electric guitar is not really meant for solo playing. Now that I’m learning it again, I think I should form a band. My son is learning the saxophone; maybe we can play together. Or maybe I can find other people my age who have had a similar experience. We could call ourselves “The Regainers!”

Text: 

There has been a lot of discussion about sleep recently. When I wrote the book *Insomniac*, about people who cannot sleep, I felt like I was the only one warning about the dangers of not getting enough sleep and how it affects our minds, bodies, and feelings. Anyone who has trouble sleeping will tell you that sleep is very important for our mental, physical, and social health. People who struggle the most with sleep often understand how important it is. It is good that sleep is finally getting attention. But what about dreams? I have not heard much about dreams in this discussion. We are losing dreams all the time. When you wake up early because of an alarm, you miss the last hour or two of sleep, and this lost sleep is mostly REM or ‘Rapid Eye Movement’ sleep, which is when we dream the most. Our most vivid and powerful dreams happen mainly in the REM stage just before we wake up in the morning. A good sleeper spends about a quarter of their sleep time in REM, so a person who lives 90 years will spend six or seven years in REM sleep. When researchers take away REM sleep from people, they find that the next night, those people have more REM sleep to make up for it. This shows that dreams are important. 

When researchers found REM sleep in 1953, many agreed with the famous psychologist Sigmund Freud, who said that understanding dreams was the best way to understand our minds. However, later studies about the brain did not support this idea. Now, researchers focus more on the physical reasons for dreams rather than the psychological ones. According to Harvard University sleep scientist Robert Stickgold, there is very little agreement among dream researchers today. 

Dreams are important. At a meeting of the Associated Professional Sleep Society, P.F. Pagel from the University of Colorado Medical School shared a study that showed actors, writers, and directors remember and use their dreams much better than other people. He concluded that the use of dreams increases with a person’s interest in being creative. It makes sense that filmmakers have a strong connection with their dreams because films are very dream-like. But I wondered, are only creative people the ones who can use their dreams? Don’t teachers, software designers, and politicians also need to think creatively? 

Stickgold says that dreams help us connect ideas in new and surprising ways, using knowledge from the past and present to find new connections. Dreams may help us see new patterns and create combinations that break our usual ways of thinking. For example, Stickgold found that when people are woken from REM sleep and asked to respond to a word, their answers are more original than when they are woken from other sleep stages. They “ignore the obvious and put together things that make a kind of crazy unexpected sense.” This is what creativity is, according to Stickgold. I find that I write better when I wake up from intense dreams. Even a difficult dream, or one I can barely remember, seems to help me think better. On those days, the words and ideas come out so quickly that I can hardly keep up with my typing. I don’t know how it works, but it does seem to help. 

But creativity is not just for writers or artists. We live in a complex world, and we all need our brains to work well. We need to think creatively and flexibly as we interact with colleagues, family, and friends. This is why we need to dream.

Text: 

Twenty years ago, Susie Ray left London to live in a small coastal town in south-west England. When you enter her studio, you see a beautiful view of the sea and many empty frames on the walls, along with smiling photos of her two daughters. Susie is a well-known copyist artist. She can copy famous paintings from the early 20th century, like those by Impressionist artists, and also works from the 16th century, like Caravaggio. It is surprising that she does not keep any of her own work. “I don’t have any of my own around,” Susie says. “As soon as I finish them, they go.” 

Susie is very popular. In her 30 years as a copyist, she has painted many famous artists’ works, including Renoir, Monet, and Van Gogh. Her copies are so good that art experts sometimes think they are the originals. While the original paintings can sell for millions of pounds, her copies sell for a few hundred pounds to £12,000, depending on how long she spends on them. Susie does not reveal most of her clients, but they include galleries and private collectors. Some collectors love art, but others want to show off their collection. One famous buyer likes to say he owns a ‘Van Gogh’ painting, but it is really a ‘Susie Ray Van Gogh’. “Many famous people pass off my copies as originals,” she says. “That’s up to them.” Some collectors keep the original painting in a bank safe and show Susie’s copy in their home.

Susie is honest about her work. When she copies an old masterpiece, she tries to make it look as real as possible because she believes it is important to respect the original artist. However, she signs her name on the back of the canvas. It is illegal to sell a copy as the real painting, and even though she knows people who have done this, she has never wanted to. People who make fake art often get into trouble. Susie is not rich and has had difficult times, but her life is more stable now, and she does not want to risk her good reputation.

Susie did not always copy paintings. After finishing her art degree, she worked as an illustrator for a botanical garden. She earned very little money for several years. Looking back, she thinks this experience helped her learn important skills and gave her a love for plants, even though it was hard to live on that salary. She had to be very accurate and get things right the first time. She has no regrets about that job, but she is happy to have found something that pays better.

When younger artists ask Susie for advice, she tells them to learn to draw well and represent things accurately. She also emphasizes how much she has studied to do her work. Her training allows her to draw plants, make perfect copies of 15th-century paintings, and reproduce 20th-century abstract art. Now, she focuses on French Impressionists, with Manet, Cezanne, and Degas being her favorites. 

Susie believes that many people think modern art is easy, almost like children’s art. However, she explains that Impressionists painted quickly and freely, but they were also very careful. This combination is harder to achieve than people think. Given her skills, it seems strange that Susie does not create her own art. Isn’t art about expressing yourself? Could a Susie Ray original be worth more than a copy? She explains that her work comes from years of training and hard work, and she makes a good living from it. She has tried to create her own art before, like oil paintings of fishing nets, but they looked too much like photographs. They were fine, but not better than that. It’s like living on simple food after enjoying meals made by a great chef. Susie is a perfectionist.

Text: 

During her racing days, Ellen MacArthur cared most about the sea and being the fastest person on it. She loved sailing since she was a child. Her boats were very important to her; they felt like a part of her. When she was back on land, everyday life seemed unimportant. People wanted to know about her races, but she just wanted to be back on the ocean, challenging nature, even in places that had been dangerous for her.

After she finished second in the Vendée Globe, a solo round-the-world race, she showed me her small boat, Kingfisher. She took me into the tiny cabin where she lived and worked for 94 days. She explained how she carefully planned everything, even how many rolls of kitchen paper she would need. Preparation was very important to her. She proudly showed me her food supplies, a small gas stove, and medical supplies. She took great care of her boat because her life depended on it.

Now, Ellen sees the world like a boat: a small, beautiful thing that can be damaged and is running out of resources. A turning point for her was a trip to South Georgia, a lonely island in the South Atlantic, where she helped with a bird survey of albatrosses. This experience made her think differently about the world. She noticed many abandoned whaling stations and felt it was a warning. She realized that people often take what they want and move on.

When I arrived at Ellen’s office, she was finishing a conference call. She explained why we need to act now to save the planet. “We are not making coal, oil, or gas anymore. They are precious resources that we have only once. We need to find ways to not use everything up,” she said. At first, her message was to use less, but she later found a more positive way to think about it. Now, she talks about re-using things, like reusable carpet tiles.

For the last three years, she has been visiting factories, mines, and power stations, talking to governments and businesses about our dependence on non-renewable resources. “I will never be an expert,” she says. “But I love learning new things. I couldn’t ignore the current situation. Sailing now feels selfish compared to this work. It’s about finding how I can be most helpful. It really matters.”

She also started the Ellen MacArthur Foundation, a charity that helps young people think about and create a sustainable future. “I do miss the adventure of being at sea,” she says. “It is part of who I am. You feel connected to everything around you. You don’t have time to feel lonely. You focus on the race, on practical things, on survival. My new message is not as simple as saying: ‘I want to be the fastest person around the world.’ I may have been the fastest, but this work is more important than anything I have ever done.”

**Simplified Text:**

Jordan Romero is 13 years old and wants to be the youngest person to climb Mount Everest. If he succeeds, he could become one of the most famous teenagers of his time. He hopes to inspire other kids to go outside and explore, instead of just playing on computers and video games. Jordan's climbing team includes his father, Paul, and his mother, Karen. They call themselves "Team Romero." Climbing Everest is just part of their plan. If Jordan climbs Everest and Vinson Massif in Antarctica, he will be the youngest person to climb the Seven Summits, which are the highest mountains on each continent. Very few people do this before they turn thirty. Jordan has already climbed five of these mountains and might finish before he becomes a teenager.

I spoke to some famous climbers who have climbed Everest, and they do not think it is a good idea to take a 13-year-old up the mountain. They believe that while a young climber might be strong, they may not be emotionally ready. They also think that a young person might not have enough experience to make good decisions while climbing safely. The Romero family has heard these opinions before. Paul says, "I know there is criticism, but I can’t focus on it – we have a lot to do. I think about possible problems, but I believe our experience as climbers will help. Watching Jordan grow gives me confidence. He is getting stronger and more mature."

I also wonder why Jordan wants to do this. Is it just his father's dream? Paul says, "This project is not about me becoming famous through my son. At first, Jordan thought about doing this later in life, but we decided, ‘Why not now?’ We talk to him often to make sure he still wants to do it." When I ask Jordan what he enjoys about the challenge, he says, "I just focus on reaching my goal."

In the past, not many people cared about being the youngest or fastest to climb a mountain or sail an ocean. Now, every adventure is shared online, and every climb is seen as a chance to break records. The more exciting the record, the more people are interested. This creates a problem for Jordan. Some people say that focusing on achievements can take away the fun of the adventure. But if Jordan wants to inspire others, he needs to use social media. This means blogging, taking photos, and giving interviews. He needs to do something amazing, like climbing Everest. Paul says, "If Jordan comes home tomorrow and says he wants to stop climbing and play basketball instead, we will end this project and go to the gym."

Text: 'When you see a teenager with an MP3 player, it is likely they are not listening to classical music. Most people can name many pop groups, but if you ask my friends about Brahms, they usually do not know who he is. I have just started a music degree, but my classmates know as little about classical music as other teenagers. If you do not know who created the music, you probably do not have any recordings of it. This is sad for fans of classical music. Last year, only 3% of concert tickets sold were for classical music events, and the average classical recording sells only 300 copies. This is hard to believe. So, why is there less interest in classical music, which has been around for centuries? Older people often blame our love for TV and video games, but I do not think this is the reason. The truth is that classical music does not attract most people, especially teenagers, who are the ones most likely to buy music and concert tickets. I know some teenagers who go to classical concerts, but they are few. Even though I play in an orchestra, I do not really enjoy classical music. I like many styles, but according to my computer, I listen to classical music about as much as that 3% figure. 

So, why don’t teenagers like classical music? First, the pace and rhythm of classical music, with its many changes, can be hard for us. We like to talk, play, and think quickly. Experts say we can only pay attention for about three minutes, which is too short for most classical pieces but just right for pop songs. Pop music is simple and easy to listen to, while understanding classical music takes time and focus. Also, pop music talks about things that interest teenagers, while classical music often does not. 

The way we listen to music has changed too. In the past, families would play music together at home, and playing an instrument was important. Now, you can find any music online, but classical music is rarely part of our daily lives. When was the last time you heard classical music in a store? One of my teachers says that more people are going to classical concerts now. Maybe, but I doubt many of them are teenagers. In my orchestra, we play classical music in many places, but when I look at the audience, I mostly see older people. I do not know why more middle-aged people like classical concerts, but I do know that if your parents love something, you might want to avoid it. Some people say schools are to blame for teenagers not liking classical music, but many kids want to play classical music in their school orchestras. They come early to practice and stay late to rehearse. They enjoy classical music when they play it, but it is not their favorite music otherwise. The two activities have become separate. When we want to relax, we always choose pop music.'

Bonnie Wyndham got out of her mother’s car and looked at Almonside School. “I’ll make you sorry I’ve come here,” she said with a smile. Her mother was getting out of the other side, so she didn’t hear Bonnie, but Bonnie didn’t mind. Her mother knew how she felt. Mrs. Wyndham looked around. Almonside was a strange school, with buildings hidden among the trees on a hillside; it was confusing at first. Then she saw signs: Science block, gymnasium, riding centre… “Riding centre,” said Bonnie, suddenly interested. “Headmaster’s study,” said her mother. “This way.” Bonnie followed her mother along a wide path between the trees. “I wish you’d walk beside me instead of following me like a dog,” said Mrs. Wyndham tiredly, but she didn’t expect Bonnie to do so. A few minutes later, her mother was talking to Bonnie’s new headmaster in his study, while Bonnie waited outside the door. Suddenly, Bonnie stood up. “Why should I just sit here?” she said to herself. “I’ll be thrown out soon anyway,” she thought, “so why not get it over with?” She left the building and went to the riding centre, following the sign. There was a nice old building for the horses and a large area for indoor riding. Bonnie looked around, but there was no one in sight. She approached the horses with respect. They were well cared for, and she could see that right away. Almost every stall was full, and she walked along, looking carefully at each horse. “I know what you’re doing here,” she told a small pony, gently touching its nose. The next horse caught her attention. “But aren’t you the best of the lot!” she said. He was brown with a bit of white. He seemed lively, which Bonnie liked. “I feel like we’ve met before,” she said, stroking his neck. “It was in my dreams, and I was riding you to victory in a big competition…” Above the stall was his name: Maverick. Suddenly, she wanted to ride the horse. “I wonder where I can find a bridle and a saddle. It can’t be far.” The room with the riding equipment was – to Bonnie’s delight – unlocked. While she was busy putting a saddle on Maverick, she forgot all about her mother and the headmaster. When she sat high on the big horse outside, she felt like a queen, in charge of everything she could see. Her nickname at her old school had been Queen Bee, and she laughed happily as she remembered it. “You’re the best horse I’ve ever ridden, Maverick,” she said, “and I mean it because I know about horses, even if I don’t know about much else.” She nudged him into a walk, then into a trot. “If I stay here, I think you and I could be great friends,” she said. She went around and around the paddock. The rhythm was exciting, with a little breeze brushing past her cheek. She could tell Maverick trusted her, and she felt sure he would jump well.

Text: "I have met Cody Simpson before and have always been impressed by his quiet confidence. The 15-year-old Australian has already released many successful songs. So how did a relaxed surfer end up on stage in front of thousands of fans? ‘I first picked up a guitar when I was six years old and started writing songs when I was seven,’ Cody says, remembering how it all began. ‘But I was swimming and surfing every day. Those things were more important to me back then; I had a busy life. When I was 13 and in high school, I posted a few videos online.’ These videos changed everything. He started by posting a video of himself and a friend singing at a school concert. Fans left comments asking for more videos. So Cody, who had recorded more at home, was happy to share them. The responses were amazing. Cody was also a talented swimmer. He trained hard with great coaches and focused on his sport. But then record labels contacted him, and he had a tough choice: stay in Australia and keep swimming, or take a big risk by signing a deal and moving with his family to the US. Cody decided to take the chance. ‘It was very hard for me – especially at such a young age – to choose a career. Can you imagine being 12 or 13 years old and trying to decide what you want to do for the rest of your life?’ He had to tell his swimming coach and friends that he was moving to the US. ‘It surprised most people. I’m kind of the quiet kid,’ he says, remembering their shocked faces. ‘I’m very modest, and I think it’s important to be that way in this crazy world.’ So Cody packed his bags and went with his family to the other side of the world, giving up one dream to try to make another one come true. Although his family stays out of the spotlight and is not directly involved in his career, they support him. Cody says it’s important to have a close group of good people around you to stay grounded. Of course, everyone has days of doubt. ‘Sometimes when I’m alone, I think, “How did my decision affect my little brother and sister?” My little brother is eight years old, and he travels the world, doing school on the road; he doesn’t have a normal life,’ Cody admits. ‘I worry about how that affects him, but my family always reassures me that they support me in everything I do.’ Success in any career comes from being willing to say ‘yes’ to your big chance, even when it’s a little scary. ‘It all happened so fast and unexpectedly,’ Cody says. ‘Now, I am going to countries I never thought I would visit and playing in front of hundreds of thousands of fans – it’s something many people dream of. But I know it won’t last forever.’"

Text: 

I jumped out of bed, pulled back a corner of the bedroom curtain, and looked down at the river. A new crack in the ice sparkled in the morning sun. I shaded my eyes and looked upstream at the sandbags, which were there to stop the buildings from flooding as the ice melted. My back still hurt from lifting the sandbags last week. I had worked with most of the adults in town for long hours to help. My grandfather didn’t seem to notice. 

With one hand on the curtain, I looked at the stretch of dark water from the factory in Milltown. There was fragile ice on both sides, and solid ice further down. As I took off my pajamas and put on my kayaking wetsuit, I saw a boy on the other side of the river. I didn’t know him. I frowned. He was trying to balance on an ice shelf near the warm water from the factory. I zipped up my wetsuit and grabbed my kayaking jacket. I checked the pocket for my lucky chain – a silver chain my famous grandfather brought back from South America. It is better than having a famous grandfather because only he, my mom, and I know about it. I also have his diary from that trip, which I keep under my pillow and read before I sleep. I touched the chain again and went to the kitchen. 

“Good morning, Rex,” my mom smiled as I took a banana from the counter. “You’re up early for a Saturday. I’ll make brunch after your training. Be careful.” 

“Thanks, Mom.” I walked down the hallway and almost bumped into my tall grandfather as he came out of his room. 

“Can’t you watch where you’re going?” he shouted. “Where are you going?” 

“Sorry, Grandpa. I’m going kayaking.” It was obvious because of my wetsuit. He always sees me in my kayak every morning. Grandpa can be hard to deal with when he gets angry. 

“What’s the point of training? You didn’t win the competition,” he said. His words hurt, but I took a deep breath and counted to three. He walked away and slammed the bathroom door. My mom came in with a kind smile. 

“Don’t mind him. He’s…” 

“...not himself right now,” I finished for her. I wanted to say he has always been like this, but I tried to be nice to him. When I was a child, he was my hero. He showed me photos of himself in National Geographic magazine. Those old photos still hang on his wall, above his dusty medals and trophies. But I don’t go into his room anymore. I have my own trophies to look at, and maybe one day, my own picture in National Geographic. Still, a part of me wants to stay loyal to him, even though he is grumpy. 

Mom smiled. “At least he is coming out of his room more. Have a good training session, Rex. I admire your determination to keep going, even in this cold weather!” 

I smiled back as I peeled my banana. “It will be warmer in South America if I find sponsors for my expedition.” 

She laughed and went back to the kitchen. I finished my banana and went downstairs. Stepping into the backyard, I hurried to the boathouse.

Text: 'Mum grabbed Jess by the arm. “Come with me,” she said. Jess followed her into the study. On the table, leaning against the wall, was an unframed painting. It was clearly one of Grandpa’s, but it looked different from his other work and was not finished. “Do you know anything about this?” Mum asked. Jess shook her head. “I’ve never seen it before. I didn’t know he was working on anything.” Jess looked closely at the painting. There was a river in it, but it was not a river she recognized. It seemed like a fantasy river. The painting was strange and beautiful in a mysterious way. The riverbank was very small, with just a hint of green that was easy to miss. The eye was drawn to the pale waters, leading to a hidden sea. There were no animals, birds, or people in the painting, and it felt right that way. It seemed like there was no place for living things in this distant scene. Still, Jess felt drawn to it, thinking about autumn coming after a long summer. Mum spoke again. “It has a name.” There was something in her voice that showed her excitement. Jess understood why. Grandpa never named his paintings. He just painted them and let others figure them out. Mum turned the painting over and pointed to the words Grandpa had written. Jess read them aloud: “River Boy.” The words felt important to her, but she didn’t know why. There was another mystery. She looked at Mum. “There is no boy.” “Exactly. It’s strange, isn’t it? For him to be so specific. But maybe he will add the boy later since he hasn’t finished it yet. I made the mistake of asking him about it.” “Mum! You should have known better.” “I know, but I couldn’t help it. It’s such an unusual painting, especially with a name. You can guess what he said.” Jess didn’t need to guess. She knew Grandpa would have said, “It’s not the artist’s job to explain a painting. Each picture has its own life and language, like a poem. We either understand it or we don’t. Painting is hard work without having to explain it to everyone.” “He said ‘ignoramus,’” Jess added. “If artists had to explain their pictures to everyone who asked, they’d never get any work done.” Mum laughed and said, “Something like that. Anyway, I was hoping you might know something about this painting since you seem to inspire him.” “Inspire?” Jess asked. “Yes, someone who gives an artist ideas.” She knew what it meant. Grandpa often said it when she watched him paint, but he usually meant that the muse was not helping him that day or that he needed to be nice to the muse. He never said the muse was about her. She always thought he meant a goddess, not a real person. It was hard to imagine anyone, even a goddess, influencing someone as strong-willed as Grandpa. “He doesn’t need me to inspire him,” she said. “He’s been painting all his life.”'

Text: 'When I woke up this morning, I didn’t mean to cut a hole in my bedroom carpet. I’m not saying it was an accident, but it could have been. For example, if I had tripped over the bed with Dad’s knife in my hand, the blade might have gone into the carpet and made a big hole. I didn’t plan to damage the carpet. I didn’t wake up and think, “Today I will cut a hole in my carpet.” It just seemed like a good idea at the time. Later, I wondered why I thought that, but by then it was too late. This happens to me a lot. 

What I was really doing was trying to fit my corner cabinet into a corner. Gran gave me the cabinet when she moved to a flat. It’s very cute! It is small, painted white, with pink and blue flowers around the edge, and has tiny glass doors. Gran used to keep china ornaments in there. I keep my collection of shells and interesting stones there. Gran knew I loved her corner cabinet, and I was so happy when she gave it to me! 

The problem is, it is a corner cabinet, so it has to stand in a corner. I only have two corners in my bedroom because it is the smallest room in the house, shaped like a wedge of cheese. The big front bedroom is Mum and Dad’s; the one at the back is my sister Angela’s; the little one over the garage is my brother Tom’s; and the tiny one belongs to me. Mum says that when Angela goes to University, Tom can have her room and I can have his. And when Tom goes to University, I can choose any room. But since Angela is only fifteen, I think I will be stuck in my small room for a long time. 

I don’t really mind; I like my little bedroom. It’s cozy, like a nest. I love the way the roof slopes down and the window is at floor level. The only problem is the lack of corners! My bed is in one corner, and my wardrobe is in the other. I tried to fit Gran’s cabinet into the space between the roof and the floor, but it was just a little too tall. If I could only cut a couple of centimeters off the bottom of it... That was when I had an idea. If I couldn’t cut anything off Gran’s cabinet, how about cutting a hole in the carpet? It seemed like the obvious solution. Dad calls this “lateral thinking.” I thought he would be pleased with me because he always tells us to “think outside the box.” And that was exactly what I was doing!'

Text: 'The novel "The Borrowers" is about a family of tiny people who live secretly in the walls and floors of a house. They "borrow" things from normal-sized people to survive. When I was asked to direct a TV version of the novel, I knew it would be hard to meet people’s expectations. Fans of the book have strong ideas about how it should be. I used the original drawings from the book a lot because I didn’t want to be told I got it wrong. The author wanted the series to show the story from the Borrowers' point of view, not from the humans', which made filming more difficult. 

The most important thing was getting the size right. The Borrowers are ten times smaller than humans, so when we filmed them walking across a room or going on a borrowing mission, we had to be ten times further away than usual. When filming the human world around the Borrowers, the crew had to crawl on the ground and film from no higher than 15 centimeters to show the Borrowers' view. They went through many pairs of jeans! We never raised the cameras above their height except for some aerial shots. 

One big challenge was getting the shadows right when we combined the tiny Borrowers with the normal-sized background. We created a special technique for this. After the series aired, famous US director George Lucas called to ask how I did it. The only permanent set we built was the Borrowers' home under the floorboards, filled with giant objects to make the actors look small. It was very surreal. I remember asking them to carry a giant pair of scissors, and they really got into it. The coins were bigger than dinner plates and hard to lift, which made the crew laugh a lot. 

In the story, there is a scene where the Borrowers are swept down a drain. To film this, actors had to go down a tunnel with hoses, and they said it was so scary that they didn’t need to act. It was important to me to get the costumes right, which has been a problem in other TV versions. I had the costumes made from heavy canvas so they looked like dolls' clothes. This made it hard for the leading actress to move. She couldn’t sit down during breaks and had to be sewn into her dress every morning. The lead actor's trousers were made from a rug because normal fabric would have looked too smooth. Unfortunately, it was very hot during filming, and I don’t think they appreciated my attention to detail with the costumes!

Most of the action away from the Borrowers' home was filmed with the actors in front of a blue screen on an empty set. It was hard for them to react to things that weren’t really there. I had to draw pictures of every scene to show how they should look – I drew 2,000 by the end. They weren’t perfect, but they worked well enough. We didn’t have enough money for special effects studios during the day, so I worked nights for three months. We had to work quickly – I once filmed a whole scene before realizing there was no film in the camera. But in the end, everything came together, and I think the series was successful in showing the magic of the books.'

Text: 'Mom stops the car at the corner of my new school, Palm Grove High School. She looks around nervously, expecting to see journalists, but there aren’t any. I know that soon there will be attention on me. It always happens. The fake smiles, the people who want to be my friends, and the ones who ask for free tickets to my dad’s concerts. “Everything will be fine,” I tell her. She kisses her fingertip and touches my cheek before I get out of the car. Then she drives away, leaving me alone in this new school and new situation. But this is what I wanted. I wanted to leave my old life of traveling and tutors. While the rest of the band is here for recording, we are staying for good. I wanted to come to this school because I want to meet regular kids. How about a kid whose mom works in an office or a dad who mows lawns? That would be so cool and normal.

I walk into the school’s main office. “Hi, I need my schedule, please,” I tell the school secretary. “Name?” She looks very unfriendly. “Desert McGraw.” “Desirée?” she asks, leaning closer. “Desert,” I repeat. The secretary seems confused. “Oh,” she says and types “McGraw” on her keyboard. That’s good because not many people recognize my last name since my dad uses a stage name. “What grade?” “Eleventh.” “One second, it’s printing,” the secretary says. Then she rips the paper and hands it to me. English Literature, first period. Great, I can handle that. English has always been my favorite subject. But I will be late. English is in Room 214 on the second floor. I studied the map last night so I wouldn’t look silly searching for my classes.

When I get to the door, I hear the teacher taking attendance. “Aurelio Gonzalez.” “Here.” I slip in quietly and sit at the last desk in the second row. The girl next to me smiles. She looks at my normal outfit – jeans and a T-shirt. Ha! Nobody will suspect me now! “Nice shoes,” she whispers. I look down at my expensive shoes with flowers on them. Oh no, I shouldn’t have worn these. “Thanks,” I say. The teacher pauses. “Desert... McGraw?” she says carefully. “Here.” The teacher smiles and introduces herself as Ms. Smigla. She talks a lot and gives us our course outlines. After we look at them and she tells us about the books we will read this year, she actually lets us talk! All teachers should understand how important this is.

“So why did you move here?” my new friend asks. I have many choices. Do I say it’s because I wanted a normal life away from cameras and reporters? Or the real reason, according to Dad? “We need a change, Desert,” he said, “and this is the perfect place to record the new album. Energy, color, culture... just what our last album needed.” Personally, I think he just wants to relax on the beach. Why else would they choose South Beach Sounds, a recording studio so close to the sand? “My dad had to move,” I tell her. Yes, lies work better. “What does he do?” she asks. Oh, whatever. Everyone will find out soon anyway. But at least I can pretend to be normal for a while. “He’s an artist,” I say, playing with the zipper on my backpack. “Cool. I’m Becca, by the way.” And she doesn’t seem to care much. Great.'

Text: 

Today, American teenage girls are expected to do a lot. They should be the president of the Student Council, have a part-time job, volunteer, and do well in school. Being a teenager in America means you cannot just go to school and be average; you need to be ambitious. Many adults forget how much pressure teenagers face today. They have a lot of homework, tests, after-school activities, jobs, chores, and they also want to have a social life. Teenager Kristen Loose says, “We have so much to do!”

Even with all this pressure, teenagers still face negative stereotypes. People often think teenagers are lazy, disrespectful, and only care about themselves. While some teenagers may fit these stereotypes, many do not. Kristen Loose believes that people wrongly assume teenagers spend all their time on their phones and watching TV. She admits she often has her phone nearby, but she uses it for important things, not just for fun. Teenagers use their phones to help with schoolwork and stay connected.

With smartphones and social media, students can do their homework anywhere. Instead of just listening to music on the way to school, they can listen to language lessons. Schoolwork now takes up a lot of their time, even outside of school. Many teenagers wake up around 6 a.m. or 7 a.m. and often stay up past midnight. They have a busy schedule filled with school, activities, family responsibilities, and homework. They usually get less than the recommended nine hours of sleep each night. A survey found that only about 20 percent of American teenagers get enough sleep, and 28 percent said they fall asleep in school at least once a week because they are tired.

Teenager Lindamarie Olsen says she has about 18 hours of free time each week. With 168 hours in a week, 18 hours is not much. She does not spend her free time on social media or TV; instead, she focuses on volunteering. She believes that many people think teenagers only care about themselves, but she enjoys helping others. “I look forward to making a positive impact in my school and community,” Olsen says.

In the future, the stereotypes about teenagers may change, but they will continue to prove people wrong and make a difference in the world. There will always be new generations of students who are ready to take on challenges before they finish school.

**Simplified Text:**

The teenage members of the Earth to Sky Calculus Club live in Bishop, a small mountain town in the US. This town is mostly surrounded by wild nature, east of the Sierra Nevada mountains. In the last few years, this group has sent over fifty balloons to the edge of space, about 35 km above the Earth. This is a long-term science project that is also an adventure, which is why many teenagers join. I visited them one weekend in late spring. They were about to release a high-altitude balloon to try to record shooting stars. Shooting stars happen when a rock or piece of metal from space enters the Earth's atmosphere and creates a bright light.

As it got dark, the teenagers attached a soft insulated $5 lunch box to the bottom of the balloon. Inside the lunch box, there was a camera, a device to measure altitude, and a thermometer to check the temperature as the balloon rose. They also put two GPS trackers on the outside of the lunch box to help find it later. A gas tank, given by a supporter from another state, was used to fill the balloon, which slowly grew to the size of a small car. An older boy made a seven-hour trip to get the gas tank. “I didn’t really mind,” he said. For kids in this club, that is normal.

Finally, it was time for the balloon to lift off. “Five, four, three, two, one,” they counted down, and the balloon started to rise. Some of the teenagers ran and followed its path with bright flashlights until they could no longer see it in the dark sky. There was a quiet moment filled with wonder. Then the balloon disappeared into the night. After the launch, most students went home, but a few stayed to watch for shooting stars. They lay on blankets on the mountainside and looked at the clear sky, which was surprising because it was only four hours from Los Angeles, a busy city with about 4 million people. I saw a boy get into a sleeping bag and quickly fall asleep. “We’re the only ones talking,” said one girl quietly. “I know,” whispered another. A meteor flew across the sky.

As the balloon rose, the air pressure decreased, and the balloon got bigger until it popped with a loud noise. A parachute helped the lunch box land safely back on Earth. The students would find it the next day using the GPS trackers. Finding it was not easy, but that was part of the fun. There is not much land with people around Bishop, so the lunch box usually lands in a remote area. “Recovering the lunch box is a big part of the program,” said the group’s leader. They have only lost two lunch boxes in 53 launches. “This journey helps us learn more about the landscape in a way we usually don’t.”

This time, the lunch box landed 84 km west of Bishop. To get it, the recovery team had to drive south of the Sierra and then back up the western side of the mountains. They had to decide whether to drive or walk, as it could be dangerous if the lunch box was on a high peak or in a tall tree. “These students know the Eastern Sierra well,” their leader said. “What seems wild to some is just normal for others.” In the end, it took them 11 hours to find the lunch box. It was in a canyon, on a flat rock, near a waterfall. The camera did not record any shooting stars. This was a bit disappointing, but it gave them a chance to discuss how atmospheric waves work above mountains. It was also another adventure story to share with anyone who asked.

Text: 

Chloe Morgan admits that she was not very interested in science, especially Palaeontology, until she was fifteen. It happened by chance. “My younger brother was really into dinosaurs, which I didn’t care about at all. I helped him with a science project, and when I read an article about new discoveries in Palaeontology, I was amazed. I knew right away that I wanted to pursue this field.”

I ask her what support she received because Palaeontology was not a common career choice for young people back then. “I remember meeting my first professional palaeontologist,” she laughs. “His name was Matt Cornelius, and he was already famous, even though he was young. I was very nervous, even though he was known to be friendly. I worried he would think I was just a kid bothering him with questions. It could have been awkward,” Chloe says. “But I felt better when he showed patience and listened to me.”

I bring up how palaeontologists are shown in movies and TV shows. Chloe thinks for a moment. “I have to say that films like Jurassic Park, which use special effects to show dinosaurs, have made many people interested in these creatures, but not necessarily in Palaeontology itself. While I appreciate this interest, I think the few palaeontologists shown in movies are often not accurate. It bothers me that we are often seen as strange geniuses or awkward people who can’t talk to others. Movies do not show the real life of palaeontologists.”

I ask her to explain her job. “My work is very varied. I spend a lot of time digging up dinosaur bones, but I also work long hours in labs, studying fossils and writing for scientific journals. Sometimes, if I have time, I also explain scientific findings to the public. I take this role seriously. There are many misunderstandings about science, and while some of my colleagues do not want to focus on this, I believe it is important. I want to connect with young people because it is essential to share all parts of science. Talking about dinosaurs can excite children about nature and help them understand other areas of science.”

The recent TV documentary Walking with Dinosaurs gave Chloe a chance to influence how dinosaurs are shown on screen. She explains that the creators of the show knew what they were doing, and she was there to give advice if needed. “I had an easy time because there was not much I needed to change, like making sure the dinosaurs were the right size and shape. I mostly checked that the dinosaurs shown lived at the same time. We attracted audiences of all ages because we have learned so much about dinosaurs recently, and the ones in this program are very different from those in movies like Jurassic Park. They are the most realistic dinosaurs ever shown.”

I ask Chloe why she thinks dinosaurs continue to fascinate us and why research on them continues. “I think they appeal to our natural curiosity. We are drawn to the unknown and the idea of discovery. In a world that feels smaller, prehistoric creatures remind us that there is still much to explore. Palaeontology is like time travel.”

Text: 

I will say this once: when you are traveling by car with your family, even if you are six years old, you know that you are not “there yet,” even when you keep asking, “Are we there yet?” The truth is, once you arrive, it is not “there” anymore; it is “here.” So if you think you might be “there” already, you should ask, “Are we here yet?” I am sure that no one wishes to be “there yet” more than the parents who hear that question over and over on long car trips. 

Think about it. Wouldn’t you rather relax in the back seat, with nothing to do? You can watch DVDs, listen to music, or do puzzles you have not finished, while the beautiful views go by outside the window. In the front seat, there is mum or dad, who gives out juice boxes and cookies, changes the radio station, and makes sure everything runs smoothly. 

“Are we there yet?” I hope not. But then someone in the car does something annoying—usually my younger brother, Tim. He might put his foot on my side of the seat. I can’t let that happen, so I put my foot on his side. Soon, he is all over my space, and a fight starts. The driver and co-pilot have to reach back and separate us while the car moves fast. They tell Tim to stay in his own seat and keep his hands to himself. This helps for a while, and we can enjoy the beautiful scenery again. 

Then, I try to read, but I feel a draft on my arm. The window is closed, so where is it coming from? Tim is next to me, breathing on me. He is not touching me, so he thinks he is not doing anything wrong. This makes me angry. Tim gets yelled at again, and the car swerves. But slowly, things calm down. 

Over the years, Dad has found ways to deal with us in the back seat. When we ask, “Are we there yet?” he often says, “Yes, we’re here. Get out of the car.” But we are still on the highway, going fast. Then he says, “Oh, maybe we’re not there yet.” This keeps us quiet for a bit. 

You can tell when you are finally “there” when the adults get out of the car and go far away from the kids who have bothered them for so long. So remember: if mum and dad are still close enough to answer your question, then the answer is: no. You are not there yet.

**Simplified Text:**

John and Zuzi Morgan have opened a café in Oxford, UK, where people can enjoy coffee and cake while playing board games. They hope that customers will love the experience and want to come back. Zuzi explains that they wanted to create a place where people can connect without using their phones and other devices. She believes that people should be together and talk to each other.

The games played in their café are called ‘Eurogames’. These games often have gentle themes, like farming and building landscapes. The first Eurogame was The Settlers of Catan, created by a German designer named Klaus Teuber. In this game, players build settlements on an island and trade resources with each other. Everyone stays involved and feels part of the game until the end.

Later, cooperative games were created, where all players work together to win or lose as a team. One popular cooperative game is Pandemic, designed by Matt Leacock from North America. In Pandemic, players must work together to solve global problems. Leacock was inspired by a Eurogame called Lord of the Rings, which is based on the book of the same name. He remembers feeling scared and excited while playing it with friends. He wanted to create a game that gave players those same feelings.

Leacock has loved board games since he was a child. He enjoyed receiving games as birthday gifts, but often felt disappointed when they didn’t meet his expectations. With help from his uncle, he started to redesign games to make them better. Pandemic became very successful, and its follow-up game included a lot of storytelling. Leacock says it is like an electronic game because players develop characters and the story changes as they play.

The growth of video games has helped the success of modern board games. Many people now play games on their smartphones, making them more open to playing board games too. Ben Hogg, who works for a game company, says that everyone has at least one game on their phone. 

In the past, video games allowed people to play together in the same room, but now many games are played online, making it harder to connect with others. Because of this, some people who enjoyed video games are looking for ways to play games with others in person again. 

At John and Zuzi's busy café, tabletop gaming has become more than just fun. In our online world, games are now something to share directly with others, and this trend is likely to continue.

**Simplified Text:**

Jamie Scott has written and produced some of the biggest hits in the UK in recent years. His story shows that hard work and determination are very important in the music business, even if your career starts slowly. He says his mother was a great singer and helped him learn to play the guitar. The only radio he listened to at home was a local station for older people, which influenced his music taste as he grew up. He was 12 years old when he first heard a modern song. Around the same time, he had to choose between playing tennis, which he played at a national level, and music. He spent his lunchtimes in the music room at school learning songs on the piano. He said, “I was doing well in tennis, but it was not what I wanted to do for my whole life. It was just too much hard work.” At 17, he left school to become a performer. He formed a duo with a friend who was a good guitarist but did not want to make a career in music. Jamie told his parents that he wanted to pursue music, saying he had been writing lyrics during economics lessons and playing the piano every day. His dad gave him 18 months to succeed; if he didn’t, he would have to find a job. After some close calls with record labels, he was signed to a music publisher at 19 because of one song. However, record labels wanted him to be a solo artist, so he had to part ways with his friend. Eventually, he became more successful as a songwriter than as a performer. After a tough time with a record label in the UK, he asked to leave and joined another label to release a new album. He did not become famous right away. He said, “I feel like I’ve been in the wrong place at the wrong time for most of my career, but as a writer, I’ve been in the right place at the right time.” Writing for other artists is where he found success. He believes he is one of the main writers in the UK that labels turn to for new artists. He sometimes has to explain to artists that wanting to write popular songs is okay. He asks them, “Don’t you want 10 million people to listen to your music next month?” He wants to help them create songs that are both amazing and likely to sell well. It is nice to hear someone in pop music talk openly about wanting to write big hits. Jamie is not arrogant; he knows he wants to write number one songs and that he has a talent for it. Instead of trying to please others, he focuses on his work. He says, “When I go into the studio with someone, we need to aim to write the best music for next year. It’s not just about what’s popular. We want to create classic modern pop songs.”

**Simplified Text:**

Tony Connor is a new kind of celebrity. He is very popular online, but many people, like me, may not know him because we don’t watch videos of people doing tricks on bikes. He is a ‘street trials cyclist.’ This means he jumps from hard places like roofs, walls, or rocks to land safely in other strange places. He films these stunts and shares them online.

On the day I interview him, we meet in a BMX park on a Saturday morning. The local kids all know who he is, and some older people come to tell him he’s ‘an absolute legend.’ After watching him perform, I agree with them. At first, I was a bit doubtful, but I am impressed by his bravery and creativity. Before each stunt, he explains what he plans to do, and sometimes I can’t believe he will succeed. When I compliment him, he seems a bit uninterested and sad. Even though he is famous online, Tony says he does not like being a celebrity. He finds it hard to connect with fans. He says, “I see the value of talking to fans, but I prefer to just do things.”

This is interesting because his fame comes from social media and the small cameras that help create the videos. He says, “This technology helps people like me earn money.” He feels that many people are always filming themselves or looking at screens, and he doesn’t always agree with that.

Tony makes a good living from his videos, which is different from the past when similar activities were just hobbies. After many years of interviewing top athletes, I have learned that two important things help a child become a great competitor: energy and the ability to handle disappointment. These qualities can be more important than talent and help someone keep going even after failing. The riskier the sport, the more mental strength is needed.

Even in the park, Tony fell a few times on what he thought were easy but new challenges. He just got back up and kept trying until he succeeded. Some people do not see him as a hero. They think he is reckless and takes too many risks. He says, “People who say this may care, but they don’t understand. They probably have never ridden a trials bike and don’t know much about the sport. They don’t see that I get advice from experts to reduce risks.”

Tony is careful about the risks he takes. He explains, “People are different. Some are never scared, and they shouldn’t do these sports. It’s smart to know the dangers. Others can’t get over their fear, but I can. I feel fear but find a way to move past it. I’m not addicted to risk; I spend a lot of time planning. Sometimes I ride around for a while to get ready before trying a new stunt. I know I must stay calm before I jump. If I focus completely, then I’m okay.”

Text: 'Television presenter Helen Skelton has done many dangerous challenges for charity, like running a marathon in the desert and traveling down the Amazon river in a small boat. For her latest challenge, Helen walked on a high wire, which is a long thin piece of metal, 66 meters above the ground, between two towers of an empty power station. There was no safety net, just a belt around her waist connected to another wire above. To help her keep her balance and not fall, she carried a long stick that weighed eight kilograms. Helen took lessons from an expert high-wire walker. Even though she already had some circus skills, she found out that high-wire walking was very different. ‘The training was a shock,’ said Helen. ‘I didn’t know how strong I needed to be. Every day started at 8 am with a run up a steep hill; then I did an hour of exercises, and another hour practicing on the wire. I also had to learn how to fall onto the wire so that if I slipped, I could keep going. Every time I fell on the wire, it hurt a lot. But I had to stay positive: if I was nervous and started shaking, the wire would shake too!’ On the day of the challenge, it was windy, and Helen controlled herself by taking deep breaths as she moved step by step along the wire. The 150-meter walk took 15 minutes. ‘That was the scariest thing I’ve done,’ she said afterwards. ‘I’m glad it’s over!’ However, this experience has not stopped Helen from planning her next charity project: to reach the South Pole by ski, kite, and bike.'

In 2006, Jeff Somers started a trip around the world on a penny farthing, an old-style bicycle with one big wheel and one small wheel. He had already written a book about his travels in Canada using a 50-year-old car. He loved motor sports and worked building racing car engines. To save money, Jeff rode an old bicycle to work and also used it to go on holiday to Amsterdam. He said, “That trip opened my eyes. I decided to see the world by bike.” Jeff did not want a regular touring bike and wanted to build one himself. He thought the most unusual bike would be a penny farthing, so he went to a museum to learn how they were made.
