After two attempts in 2001 and 2003, when he had to stop because of a knee injury, he finally began his journey in 2006. He traveled for three years, visiting 23 countries on four continents. The best part of his trip was arriving in Tibet and seeing Mount Everest. He met other cyclists who could ride up mountains, but he never regretted using his penny farthing. The further he traveled from home, the more surprised people were by his bike. His worst moment was when he had to drink dirty water from a stream, which made him very sick. He spent ten days in a hostel without medicine and had no money for a hospital or to go home. Despite all this, Jeff now says, “If I could afford it, I would start traveling again tomorrow on my penny farthing.”

Text: "I work at a university in the US with my team to learn more about water birds, especially the American black duck. We have just started using a new tool called a ‘night-vision scope’. This tool helps us see the ducks in the dark! We are worried about black ducks because their numbers have dropped a lot, and we don’t know if there is enough food for them on the east coast. We have a lot of information about what they do during the day, but we know very little about their night activities because we didn’t have the right equipment. This new scope will give us clear pictures, even on nights without a moon, so we can learn more and make better choices about how to protect their habitat. 

It is hard work. There are four of us, and we each work six hours a day. We have studied ducks in different places, and I have had to take a boat to some locations and write down notes on every duck I see. The weather has not been easy – some nights are warm, but most of the time it is wet. It is very quiet, so I have needed a lot of coffee to stay awake! We have only missed one workday because the snow was too deep for our special snow vehicles. I enjoy the challenge, especially when I think about the summer – we will spend hours in a laboratory looking at our results together. It will be hard to be inside, but it is important to do this work. I wouldn’t change it for anything!"

Text: "When I tell people what I do for work, they often can't believe it. But I’m serious! I spend my days at work eating chocolate! Tasting chocolate is very important to make sure that customers get the best quality chocolate from my company. Every week, I get samples, which are small amounts of chocolate, from our factory. I check them for taste, texture, and smell. I also taste the raw materials we use, like nuts and fruit. I spend time choosing the best ones to put in the chocolate. Next to my office, I have a kitchen where I can test and taste the products I make. I also share samples with my colleagues! My kitchen has many machines and ingredients to use. It’s great to have a private space to go to during the day. No two days are the same in this job. Sometimes I am in our food lab, and other times I travel to buy our raw materials. This can be hard because I have a young family. But I love the variety in my job, even more than the chocolate! People often ask me if I get bored of chocolate. I’ve worked with it for a long time, and I still love to eat it. In fact, I often go home and eat more chocolate in the evening!"

Text: 'Have you ever thought about what it’s like to perform in a circus? Sophia Grayson works at Circus Experience, a place that teaches young people circus skills. She says her course is popular because it teaches many skills, like juggling, throwing and catching balls, and even fire. It also includes trapeze, where performers fly through the air in front of an amazed audience. 

In the year-long course, students slowly take more risks in each class, and parents can come to some classes to see how their children are doing. Sophia explains, “For a circus career, performers need to do different things all the time – it’s important to keep performances exciting and full of action. If you want to be successful in the circus, you must keep practicing. Another great part of this job is making friends with other performers and learning from them. Being fit is also very important - circus artists, like athletes, train every day to stay strong. Training is very important, but the best performers are those who want to succeed, have creativity, and always work on improving their skills. 

People often think that circus performers get hurt a lot or that they only work for a short time each year. But the real issue is thinking about the future because you can only travel and perform while you’re young, and then you need to think about other options.” The course also teaches business planning. Many past students have started their own businesses around the world and are happy to share their experiences. However, Sophia warns that it’s not a job for making a lot of money! “The work usually does not provide a regular salary. It’s also competitive - but a lot of fun!”'

Text: 'You may not know her name or face, but you have probably heard her many times. Mariam Hobson is a professional backing singer. This means she sings in the background to support the main singer. Many people think backing singers are not good enough to be lead singers, but that is not true – they often have to be even better. People like Mariam are the real stars of the music industry! 

“What I love about my job is that when I walk into the recording studio, I never know what I will be asked to sing,” she says. “It could be classical, jazz, hip-hop, or rock. Sometimes, it might be a funny song for a radio station or an advertisement. I am often surprised by what the producers ask me to do. Once, I was asked to sing like a fish underwater! But I never argue; I just do my job!”

“Excellent musical skills are very important for my work, and I need to learn quickly. There is often no written music to follow. I will never forget my first time recording background music for a film. It was very complicated because there were eight of us, each singing a different part, along with an orchestra. I was scared because if I made a mistake, we would have to record everything again, and nobody likes that. Recording sessions are long enough already.”

“One of my favorite jobs is recording for songwriters. Less experienced writers do not always know which musical range is best for a female voice. By listening to me sing their song, they can figure out how to improve it.”'

Text: 'Julie Deane started with only basic knowledge of fashion, but she created a successful business selling ‘satchels’ - a traditional bag used by schoolchildren. These satchels are now sold in famous shops and are popular with many celebrities. Before deciding to sell satchels, Julie made a list of different business ideas, like cake decorating and party planning. She thought carefully about her options instead of just choosing the first idea. When she decided to sell satchels, not everyone agreed with her. Julie said, “Many people said there was no demand for them – but I was sure.” She involved her family from the beginning, working with her mother, who had never had a job but was good at business. The design of the satchels was inspired by children’s storybooks. 

Although Julie didn’t know much about fashion blogs, they became important for her success. At first, she sold about one satchel a week. To create interest, Julie sent satchels to fashion writers and hoped they would write about them in their blogs. They did, and interest in her satchels grew, as did the speed at which her company made them. Now, Julie enjoys waiting to see which celebrity will be seen with a satchel! While other companies spend money on online ads, she uses the internet community for ideas for new styles, keeping her products fresh and exciting. 

There was a difficult time when another company copied Julie’s design to sell similar bags. Because of this, she now makes sure she trusts her production team as much as her own staff. Visitors often comment on the positive atmosphere in her offices – people enjoy working there. There is now a new factory, and while the buildings are important, it is the team that makes it a special place.'

Text: 'When Vicky Harmiston was a child, her parents let her and her brother Jamie choose what to do in their free time. Vicky liked to do many different sports. She was a good swimmer, and her coach at the swimming club thought she could become a champion. But the club was far from her home, so it was hard for her to fit training into her school schedule. When they were teenagers, Jamie, who loved cycling, bought a special racing bike and started competing. Vicky thought it looked exciting and decided to try it too. She says that was the best decision she ever made. Soon, she was cycling every day and doing very well. The track was close to her school, so it was easy for her to go to training after school. Vicky had a successful career in track cycling and won several competitions. Then, when she was 28, she stopped competing. Vicky said, ‘For years I loved winning, but I started to feel tired of it all – and when the excitement goes away, there’s no point. Luckily, I found a new job.’ Vicky got a job with a charity called CycleZone. ‘We work with young people who have never enjoyed sports,’ she says. ‘The first thing we do is teach them to ride a bike. We want them to believe in themselves and their abilities. CycleZone does a great job, and it brings young people together so they feel part of a group.’ The charity uses famous people to promote their work. Vicky says, ‘I know some people think the support of a celebrity is not always good for a charity. They say celebrities only do it for their own benefit, which makes it hard for the public to see the real work of the charity. But if famous singers and actors can help, I think they should.’

Text: 'Ana Ronson is a singer-songwriter from Ireland. Her parents were not musicians, but there was always music in her home. Her grandfather played the guitar and taught Ana and her brother how to play. The first time Ana sang in front of people was at school. She was very nervous, and her teacher had to help her off the stage. The teacher suggested that Ana join the school theatre club to help her feel more confident. After some time in the club, she sang happily with 50 other students at a concert at the end of the term. 

A year later, her brother, who was in a band, asked her to write a song for them. She wrote her first song, called Falling Stars, in just three days. She enjoyed it so much that she signed up for a songwriting course with a professional songwriter. Even though she was the youngest student, she knew more about music than many others. However, Ana felt that the teacher did not listen to her, so she wrote a song called Something to Say about her feelings. She shared this song online, and it became very popular. She was happy when people commented that they loved it and found new meanings in the lyrics.

Joss Alton, who owns a recording company called Isotope Music, flew from the other side of Ireland to ask Ana to join his company. At first, she was unsure because she did not know much about Isotope and did not want anyone telling her what to sing. But Joss convinced her that this would not happen. Soon after, she performed at a concert in Dublin organized by Isotope. All the tickets sold out quickly, and it was a wonderful evening.

Ana prefers to write songs about difficult times in life rather than happy moments because she feels she has more to say then. One of her favorite songs is Decision, which is about why her brother stopped singing for a while and how it made him unhappy. While she hopes her fans will enjoy her songs, her goal is to write about personal experiences that are important to her.'

Text: 'Last year, I went on a wonderful trip – traveling by boat on a guided group tour along the west coast of Canada. It was my brother Harry’s idea. He is a journalist, like me, and he wanted to write articles about the trip. He loves boats, but I don’t share that interest. I had always wanted to visit this area since I saw it on TV as a child, especially because our great-grandparents lived there before moving to Europe. So, I kept asking Harry if I could go too – until he finally said yes! A few days before we left, there were storms in the area we were going to. But luckily, the weather forecast for our trip was good. I was busy at work and didn’t have much time to prepare, but Harry promised he would take care of everything, so I stopped worrying. 

After arriving in Canada, we joined the group, packed our supplies into small boats, and set off. The guide said that very few people live along that coast now, and the only other living creatures we saw that first morning were dolphins and birds. We knew there were islands in the distance, but the early-morning fog made it hard to see far, so I just focused on the beautiful patterns our boat made in the water. We often stopped for hours to explore the rock pools on the beaches. They were full of colorful fish, many of which I didn’t know. It was nice to forget about how fast or slow the day was going. We never forgot lunch or dinner, though, which we all cooked together over campfires. When we finally fell asleep on the boats each evening, even though the beds were hard, it felt like a stress-free life! When it was time to leave, I felt sad. How could I go back to normal life? But I knew if I stayed, I would miss my family and friends. I was also excited to tell everyone at home about our adventures!'

Text: "My dad was a professional basketball player in Germany, just like his father before him. When I was a kid, I went to watch many of his games. You might think that watching so many matches would make me love basketball, but it did the opposite. I liked telling my friends how good my dad was, especially when he won, but I usually took a book to read instead of watching the games.

When I started secondary school, I was still two years away from being a teenager, but I was already two meters tall. Because of my height, my sports teacher asked if I wanted to train with the basketball team. I enjoyed the practice, but I thought I needed to get better before playing in a real match. The teacher believed in me more than I believed in myself. After some time, I agreed to play, and a few weeks later, I found myself in a game against another school. My parents came to watch, which made me more nervous, but it turned out fine!

For the next four years, I practiced every day and did really well. I even joined an adult team before I moved to a special sports academy in the USA when I was fifteen. The coach there trains Olympic basketball players, and it was amazing to work with him. However, I didn’t enjoy living far from my parents at first. At home, I hadn’t spent much time with my friends because of all the training, so that part wasn’t too different for me. In the end, I got used to my new life, and my English improved quickly too!

I became a professional player at eighteen, three years after arriving in the USA. I had been taller than most players in the professional league since I was fifteen, but I needed to gain weight to match my height. My coach knew a team that would take me while I was still in college, so I joined them and have never regretted it."

Text: "Seven years ago, I was studying Tourism at college, but I needed a part-time job because my course was expensive. After thinking about different options, I trained to be a weekend tour guide in my home city, Chicago, USA. This meant taking visitors around the city, and I was surprised to find out how much I enjoyed giving those tours. I got to see the city I had lived in my whole life through the eyes of tourists, and it felt like a new experience every time! After finishing my studies, I decided to become a full-time tour guide. I thought it would be easy, but when I researched what I needed to do, I learned that to get a license as a full-time tour guide, I had to know a lot more than I had learned so far. All Chicago guides must be able to answer many questions about the city, including local architecture, history, and public transport rules. After several challenging but interesting months, I got my tour guide qualification and registered as an independent tour guide. 

Tour guiding isn’t just about knowing historical facts or keeping track of your group in crowds. There are many other important skills. You should be entertaining and tell interesting stories, and most importantly, you need to react to changing situations. For example, if a place you thought was open is actually closed when you arrive, or if the route changes. Tourists don’t want to hear about problems or that they are missing something; they just want to enjoy a well-organized tour. I need to make sure visitors are happy with my tours, or they might leave a negative review online. Like most tour guides, I know that these reviews are very important because good reviews attract more customers. That’s why making tours fun and stress-free is essential. For me, the enthusiasm and energy I put into my job mean that my reviews are usually very good, and my tours are often recommended to other visitors coming to Chicago."

Text: "My name is Ella, and I am 22 years old. Last year, I went to Thailand for two weeks with my sister, Josie. She is five years younger than me, but we get along well. We went to help as volunteers at an elephant sanctuary, which is a place where people take care of sick and rescued elephants. At first, I was not sure if we would have much in common with the other volunteers because they were all older than us. We were also nervous because it was our first time doing something like this. In the end, we had nothing to worry about. 

One of our main jobs at the sanctuary was to collect food for the elephants. Elephants eat a lot of grass and banana plants, so this took most of the day. Josie found it very hard work, but I thought it was worth it to see the elephants enjoy their food. We also helped wash the elephants in the river with big brushes and soap. I had a lot of fun, even though I got wetter than the elephants!

The part of the day I looked forward to the most was the evening. By the light of the moon, we led the elephants into the forest where they spent the night. All the volunteers stayed in the same house. Josie and I shared a bedroom, so we did not have much space. We chose to do this because Josie did not want to be alone. It was hot and humid, especially at night, but we expected that. The meals were delicious and did not include meat, which we both do not like. 

After dinner, all the volunteers and staff spent the evenings talking and playing games. Now that we are back in the UK, Josie does not often talk about Thailand. But if someone asks her if she enjoyed her time at the sanctuary, she says she loved it. However, I think she might be a little upset with herself for not enjoying her time there more because she missed her friends. But when she thinks back, she can see how lucky she was to go there. Maybe she will go back one day – I know I will!"

Text: "My name is Gina D’Costa, and I own a flower shop in the UK. We sell flowers to many different customers, not just people buying for friends or their homes. Hotels and offices often buy flowers for their reception areas, and sometimes we provide flowers for businesses to use in their advertising photos. Once, I even decorated a castle with flowers for a wedding. It was a lot of work, but I was very proud of what we did. 

My day starts at 4 a.m. when I go to the market to buy fresh flowers. Most people are still asleep, and my friends think I am crazy, but I love what I do. It is often cold and dark at that time, but I don’t let it bother me. The flower market is amazing, with flowers from all over the world. The sights and smells make it hard to choose. If I were buying for myself, I would probably only choose pink flowers because it is my favorite color. But I have to remember that what I like may not be what other people want. 

Sometimes, I cannot find the flowers that customers want because not all flowers are available all year. I don’t like arguing about prices with the flower sellers, but it is part of my job. Flowers can be expensive, so I try to get the best price. 

Back at the shop, we look at customer orders and prepare vases with the flowers I bought. Then we create flower bunches and calculate the costs of the orders. Customers are often surprised by the prices, and I sometimes have to ask them to think again about what they want. Some people might think this is too much trouble, but I enjoy finding the best flowers for the money someone wants to spend. That is what you have to do when you sell things – I wouldn’t want any other job!"

Text: "My city has a modern cinema that shows all the latest films and many films for kids on weekends. It is close to my home, but a year ago, I realized something was missing – I wanted to talk about a film in detail with a group of people after watching it. So, I started a film club with two friends! We decided not to rent a cinema to show the films. Instead, we choose a different place in the city each month. For example, we rented an old factory to show a film set in Antarctica. It was very cold, which made the atmosphere perfect for the film, and it was amazing! Some places we use are free because the owners sell snacks during the film, so we can keep our prices low. We are happy to make enough money to cover our costs – we are not trying to make a profit. Each time we show a film, it gets a bit easier for us, especially now that we have our own reliable equipment. We can also see how many tickets we have sold because everything is online – no more worries about empty seats! There is always a lot to do, but when people of all ages come up at the end to say they had a great time, it feels wonderful. The website has been very helpful, and we are now in contact with other film clubs across the country. We have visited other places to see how they do things, but it is always nice to return to our own club! We have also started a blog because we know that most people look online for information about films instead of reading local papers. We have tried putting up a few posters in cafés, but nothing is as successful as people telling their friends about us. The audience loves the special activities we have with each film – last month, we had a movie quiz that everyone enjoyed."

Text: "Taking photographs was always my favorite activity when I was a child. When I turned 15, I wanted to make my hobby more special. So, I decided to start a personal project: I would take one photograph every day for a whole year. Many other young photographers had done this before, but I thought it was a great idea, so I began. After a few weeks, I decided to share my photos on a website for young photographers. I wanted to create a photo diary and show my work to others. I was surprised to find that people liked how I saw and took photos. I also enjoyed photographing many different subjects. Then someone suggested that if my photos had a common theme, my project would be even better. I agreed and started to focus more on taking photos of nature, especially birds and the sky. Many of my photos were black and white, which was different from what other young photographers were doing, as they mostly took color photos. Because of this, I sometimes doubted my project and almost gave up. In the end, I trusted my feelings and became more confident in my style and choices. One day, I showed my project to my art teacher. She told me about a national photography competition for people my age, so I entered some of my photos just for fun. I will never forget the moment when the judges told me I had won first prize; I was so happy because my project meant a lot to me. It was the first time I realized that my photography might be good, and that I could work as a professional photographer. Now, I have my own photography studio, and I have never regretted my choice of career."

Text: 'I joined the National Youth Challenge (NYC) last year because I wanted to try new things like camping, sailing, and public speaking. In the NYC, you can do different activities to challenge yourself and learn new skills. There are levels from beginner to advanced, led by adult volunteers called ‘leaders’. When you finish each level, you get a certificate. 

When I first joined, my leader suggested that I help organize activities at a local children’s club for two hours a week. I was unsure about this because I had joined that same club when I was eight and found it hard to make friends. I was shy, and the other children already had their own friends, so I stopped going after a few weeks. However, I decided to take the challenge because I wanted my first NYC certificate. 

Soon, I wanted to spend all my free time at the children’s club. It became more important to me than just getting the certificate. When I finished the challenge, the NYC leader let me keep volunteering at the club because I had made great friendships with the children. Now, I go there for about four hours a week and I always look forward to it. 

Because of what I learned at the children’s club, I decided that when I finish school in three years, I want to go to college to become a youth worker, someone who works with children. I had never thought about my future job before starting at the club. This has been my favorite part of the NYC, and I have improved my communication skills while helping others. I now have several NYC certificates, and one of them is for camping!'

Text: "I was born in Denver, USA, and I started snowboarding when I was eight years old. My dad took me to a ski resort in the mountains, which is about two hours from Denver. The hill looked very steep, so my dad had to convince me to try snowboarding. I was too young to ask him if I could start, but he loved snowboarding and wanted me to enjoy it too. He made it look easy, and in the end, I did well. After that, I quickly fell in love with the sport and got better at it. I began competing when I was ten. Some people enter many competitions and get bored, but my love for competing and winning has grown as I got older. This helps me to work harder. I like not having a strict plan, and sometimes this works out well, like when I became the first female to get a perfect score of 100 at a local competition. I wasn’t sure I could do the jumps that got me this score until I tried. That success made me trust my abilities more. In the summer, I focus on training and studying when there is no snow. I train every day, but it’s nice not to follow a strict diet like I do in winter. I also spend a lot of time with my friends then. This helps me deal with not being able to do what I love and what I am good at. I think carefully about my future. Snowboarding is a big part of my life now, but I also want to have another option in case I don’t become a professional snowboarder or if I get hurt. I am thinking about becoming a doctor if I can find time to go to college. I can’t imagine getting tired of snowboarding, but I know I can’t do it forever."

Text: 'When I was fifteen, I wanted everything my friends had, and I never thought about the future. For example, I didn’t know what I wanted to do after school. One day, my best friend got a new phone for her birthday, and I wanted one too. My parents said I could only have it if I paid for it myself, so I decided to work part-time and save money. I am thankful to my parents for making me do that – it taught me an important lesson. I worked every Saturday in a café, but I didn’t enjoy it much, so my parents suggested I start my own small business. I had seen my mum making necklaces, so I asked if I could try that. I never thought it would be so easy, as it looked complicated when I watched Mum. My friends thought it sounded boring, but I was excited about it. Mum showed me that I could create something nice at home with simple tools and materials. I sold my first pieces of jewellery to my friends and family as soon as I finished making them. They said they loved them, but I thought they were just being nice. Even though I was happy they bought them, I still needed to know if they looked good enough for other people. The only way to find out was to rent a market stall with my mum. There are many tourists where I live, and they bought a lot of my items to take home. Soon, we started getting calls from all over the country from people wanting to buy more. They thought we were a big company with many workers, but we were just two people at a market stall! That was when I knew it could work, and it was time to create a website. Since then, I’ve made a lot of money through my business, mostly online, but we still have our stall too. It has been a lot of fun so far.'

Text: 'When Janine Stuart was only 13 years old, she wrote a novel called Being Amelia, which became very popular. Being Amelia is partly based on Janine’s own life. In an interview about her book, Janine said, “Because of my father’s job, my family moved around the country a lot, so I learned how to make new friends. I know what it’s like to be the only new student in a class, and that helped me write about how the main character, Amelia, fits in at a new school. Some of the funniest parts of the book are about Amelia’s home life, especially her relationship with her older brother. Since I am my parents’ only child, I had to use my imagination to describe that.” 

Janine started her novel one summer when she was bored at home. Her mother had always wanted to be a published author, and her teachers encouraged her to write, so it felt natural for Janine to write. The year before, she entered a short story competition on a young writers’ website and won first prize. That’s why, when Janine finished Being Amelia and sent it to a publishing company, they were excited to read it. They loved it, and a year later, Janine’s novel was in bookshops. 

One review of Being Amelia says that even though the book has pictures of happy teenagers on the cover, the characters face some difficult challenges, which makes them believable. The reviewer mentions that even though Janine is still very young and Being Amelia is not a long novel, she has shown that she is a better writer than many other bestselling authors. Janine is still getting used to being a famous writer: “At first, I hid when people recognized me in the street, but now it’s OK. I want to give advice to other young writers, but they need to find what works for them. For me, I know that if I spend time with my friends, I will soon have something interesting to write about!”'

Text: "My name is Tom, and I am fifteen years old. Three years ago, my family and I moved to a castle on a small island. It all started when my father was asked to be the manager of the castle. He works for a group that takes care of historical buildings and keeps them open for visitors. He was happy because he thought this was a great opportunity, but it took some time for the rest of us to agree that he should take the job. We were worried about what life on the island would be like. We knew the castle might not be as comfortable as our warm home across the water, and there was no school there. 

After we moved, we quickly got used to living on the island. The castle is not very beautiful, but our apartment in it is nice. In the summer, the island is lively because many visitors come, and there are often beach parties. In winter, we only see the other families who live on the island, and there are not many teenagers like me. The adults help each other and work hard to fix things on the island. 

The biggest change for me was taking a boat every day to my old school. I looked forward to going on stormy days when there are big waves, but the ferries do not run then! I also found out that if I miss the bus to the harbor after school, I miss the last ferry home, which is stressful. So when my friends come to visit, I always tell them to hurry! But we often see amazing views, especially when the sun sets over the sea. Some days, it is so foggy that you cannot see anything, but then it can be bright and sunny again in just a few hours. It still feels incredible when that happens, even after living here for a long time. Of course, we do have terrible storms, and I sometimes wonder if the castle is strong enough to stay safe. But then I remember it has been here for hundreds of years, and it is still standing!"

Text: 'I live in a house in the beautiful countryside of Scotland. I have always loved nature and wild animals. Six years ago, I started a new hobby – birdwatching! I went to some mountains in northern Scotland with my family, where we saw many birds in their natural homes. I spent hours watching them with my parents, who taught me how to tell different bird species apart and where to find the best places to see them. It was amazing! After we returned home, I joined a local birdwatchers’ club for young people. My goal is to see 200 different bird species, and I am almost there. On family holidays abroad, I have seen birds from other countries, too. We always look for places with birdwatching activities so I can add new birds to my list! I have been to Egypt, and last summer we went to South America, where I thought I would see my 200th species. I was not too disappointed when it didn’t happen because I learned that you have to be patient with this hobby. I posted a video online about this challenge, and many teenagers liked it and said it looked like a fun hobby. When my teachers saw it, they asked me to give a presentation about birdwatching at school. I didn’t feel nervous until just before I walked onto the stage. I knew I would remember what to say and had some notes to help me, but the whole school and all my friends were watching! I only relaxed when it was over, and the teachers said I had prepared well and they enjoyed it. I might even do another presentation next year! I am lucky to live in the countryside. I understand why many teenagers in cities might not think about becoming birdwatchers, but there are many birds to see, especially in places with lots of green areas. I also think that birdwatching clubs should try to get more young people interested in this hobby. Everyone needs to connect with nature, no matter their age, and it doesn’t have to cost much money.'

Text: "I started playing football when I was 7 years old. I would hurry home from school to play with other kids. I loved it, and after some time, I became a good player. My family knew I often liked new hobbies but then stopped doing them, so they thought I would do the same with football. But I didn’t. I even dreamed of playing football professionally when I grew up. The chance came sooner than I expected. I played in local tournaments, and one referee saw that I was a good player. He asked the manager of a professional women’s club to watch me play. After that, she invited me to join her club. I was surprised because I didn’t know young girls could join women’s clubs. But the manager liked me, and I started training with a big club when I was 13 years old. After that, I got much better. Still, some people were not sure I would ever be a star player, which made me a little sad. But my coach told me to be myself and believe in myself. He even let me play in one of the club’s championship matches earlier than I thought I would! I ran very hard because I didn’t want to let the other players down. Then, by chance, I scored the winning goal. Even with a big crowd, I could hear my coach cheering for me, and after the match, my team carried me around the field. It was amazing! Since then, I have scored many more winning goals! Next month, my coach and I are organizing a football tournament in my area. The goal is to get teenagers interested in football and to let them talk to other players in my club. It will show them what a professional environment is like and encourage them to think they could play for a top team if they work hard. My advice to them will be the same as my coach gave me – there will be good times, but also some bad times. I have had very few bad times, so I feel lucky!"

Text: 

In recent years, there has been an interesting change in education in the UK and around the world. Schools and universities are encouraging new students to get involved in research early in their studies. This shows that research is not just for famous scholars or scientists, but is a natural way to build knowledge and skills. Research skills are important not only for studying but also for jobs, as they help us think about the world and how to do our work.

As a student, you contribute to knowledge. You do not just learn and repeat information; you create it. Making knowledge involves asking questions instead of just accepting things as they are. You might wonder: Why? How? When? What does this mean? What if things were different? These questions are at the heart of research.

Research can be seen as a range of activities. On one end, there is complex and groundbreaking research done by highly trained experts. On the other end, research can be simple inquiries that involve careful work and thoughtful questions about different issues and practices. Most students have done some form of research before. You have likely asked questions and looked for answers in school or at work since you started learning. You have also developed research skills when planning a holiday, growing plants, fixing things at home, training your dog, or shopping online.

In college and higher education, it is important to have a curious mind, identify problems, and critically explore information and ideas. You are expected to create your own responses and add to discussions. Some students may find this difficult because, in some cultures, knowledge is seen as fixed, and learning comes from listening to teachers and texts. It may feel disrespectful to question established knowledge, and you might think you should be told what is important to learn. However, in many places like the UK, US, Europe, and Australia, questioning established knowledge and authorities is encouraged.

This process of inquiry and building knowledge can seem challenging. Critical thinking is very important in research. The research done by others is helpful for students and in the workplace, but we need to engage with it. We should not just repeat what we read as if it is always true. Instead, we should think about it, test it, and check if it makes sense and is supported by evidence. We must be careful not to accept information uncritically, whether it comes from reading or speaking.

Text: 'Cities have always been important places for ideas and creativity. In the 18th century, coffee houses in London were popular spots where people talked about science and politics. In modern Paris, cafés on the Left Bank were where artist Pablo Picasso shared his thoughts on art. However, living in a city can be difficult. The same cafés in London that encouraged discussion also helped spread diseases like cholera, and Picasso eventually moved to the countryside. Today, cities are full of creativity, but they can also feel overwhelming and unnatural.

Scientists are now studying how city life affects our brains, and the findings are surprising. It has been known for a long time that city life can be tiring, but new research shows that living in a city can actually make it harder for us to think clearly. One major reason for this is the lack of nature in cities. Studies have shown that hospital patients heal faster when they can see trees from their windows. Even small views of nature can help our brains because they give us a break from the busy city life.

This research comes at a time when more people than ever are living in cities. Instead of living in open spaces, we are packed into concrete areas with many strangers around us. It has become clear that these crowded environments can affect our mental and physical health and change how we think. For example, when walking down a busy street, our brains have to pay attention to many things: people walking, busy roads, and confusing street layouts. These small tasks can tire us out because cities have so many things to focus on. Our brains need to constantly decide what to pay attention to, which takes a lot of energy.

In nature, however, we do not have to work as hard to pay attention. This idea is called attention restoration theory, created by psychologist Stephen Kaplan. He believed that being in nature could help our brains recover. Natural places have things that catch our attention without causing stress, unlike loud noises like police sirens. This allows our minds to relax and recharge.

Long before scientists studied this, philosophers and landscape designers warned about the negative effects of city life and looked for ways to bring nature into cities. Parks, like Central Park in New York, give people a chance to escape the busy city. A well-designed park can help our brains feel better in just a few minutes. While people have tried many ways to improve brain function, such as energy drinks or changing office designs, nothing seems to work as well as simply taking a walk in nature.

Given the many mental challenges of city life, we must ask: Why do cities keep growing? And why do they still inspire creativity, even in our digital age? Recent research from the Santa Fe Institute shows that the same crowded features of cities that can make it hard to focus – like busy streets and many people – are also linked to innovation. The ‘concentration of social interactions’ is a key factor in urban creativity. Just as the crowded streets of 18th-century London led to new ideas, the busy environment of 21st-century Cambridge, Massachusetts, helps it succeed as a center for technology and creativity. On the other hand, less crowded areas may produce fewer new ideas over time.

The challenge is to find ways to reduce the stress of city life while keeping its benefits. Because there will always be times when people say, ‘I’m tired of nature; take me to the city!’'

**Simplified Text:**

Where should we look for the mind? This question may seem strange because we usually think that thinking happens inside our heads. Today, we have advanced brain imaging techniques to show this. However, I believe that studying the mind should not only focus on what is inside our bodies. There is a lot of evidence, from ancient times to now, that shows that objects, as well as our brains, are important for how we think. 

From an archaeological point of view, it is clear that tools, jewelry, carvings, clay tokens, and writing have played an important role in human development and the creation of our minds. Therefore, I suggest that what is outside our heads can also be part of our minds. It is easy to think of the mind and the brain as the same thing. Most of what we know about the mind comes from studying people without the objects they usually use. This makes sense for scientists who study the brain, but it often ignores that much of our thinking happens with the help of things around us. 

I do not want to say that our thinking is not based in the brain, but I want to show that the mind is more than just the brain. It is better to explore the idea that human intelligence goes beyond our bodies into culture and the material world. This is where my new theory, called Material Engagement Theory (MET), comes in. MET looks at how objects can help us think, like when we make numbers and symbols from clay or use a stone to create a tool. It also studies how these ways of thinking have changed over time and what those changes mean for our thoughts.

This approach gives us new ideas about what minds are and what they consist of by changing how we understand the role of objects in our thinking. For example, think of a blind person using a stick. Where does this person’s self begin? The connection between the blind person and the stick helps us understand that minds and objects can work together. The stick helps the blind person feel their surroundings, and the brain treats the stick as part of the body. 

The blind person’s stick reminds us that human intelligence can change a lot by using new tools. I see the human mind as something that is always changing and developing. It is important to remember that, no matter what form the “stick” has taken throughout history – from the first stone tools to the internet – its main purpose is to help us connect with the world, not to limit us. 

For humans, tools are used to satisfy our curiosity. This special ability to engage with objects explains why humans, more than any other species, create things, and how those things shape our minds. I call this metaplasticity – our minds can change and grow as we interact with the material world. I want to bring the importance of objects back into how we understand thinking. MET offers a new way to see how different tools, from ancient hand-axes to modern smartphones, have helped define and change who we are and how we think. While the idea of technology changing our minds may sound futuristic, humans have been using it since the beginning of our existence.

Text: "Few inventions have changed our lives as much as photography. This is especially true in the United States, where photography quickly became part of American culture. It was used in many ways: for practical purposes, science, industry, and art, as well as for fun and entertainment. Historians say that photography is one of the greatest contributions of the United States to the visual arts. No other art form has been as important in the US. This is a big statement, but it shows how photography has become central to American culture and thinking. To understand its impact, we need to look at its beginnings in the mid-19th century.

Why was photography so popular? First, it was a mechanical process that matched the growing interest in technology. People were excited about changes in their lives. Just like steam power, railroads, and electricity made communication and travel easier, photography brought the sights of the world into people's homes in a very immediate way. 

Second, the camera became a popular tool for showing one's identity. It allowed people to create images of themselves for others to see, in a country where personal and national identities were always changing. Third, the camera helped families keep a record of their lives, even if those records were sometimes idealized. Finally, the realistic nature of photographs matched the trend towards realism in American art.

Every photograph draws attention to something specific, showing what the photographer wants us to see. Because photographs are made by machines, they are records of events, people, and things. They show what was in front of the camera, giving them a sense of objectivity. However, since each photograph is taken by a person, it also carries the photographer's point of view. 

When we see a photograph, we might think we understand its meaning, especially if we recognize the subject. This is why photography has often been called a 'universal language.' But the meaning of a photograph is more complicated than that. Objects, people, or events do not speak for themselves, and every image comes with some context that affects how we understand it. This could be a caption in a newspaper, a layout in a magazine, or its position in a gallery or book.

To understand a photograph in its historical context, we need to consider its purpose and function in its culture: Why did the photographer take the picture? How did people first see it? The same image can be viewed in different places and times, and its meaning can change accordingly.

For a long time, the importance of the camera to artists was not well known, but today it is clear. In recent decades, artists like Andy Warhol have used photographs in their work in many ways. In summary, photography has become an important part of art, working alongside painting and shaping our ideas of representation before the camera was invented."

In 1890, William James, an American philosopher and doctor, defined psychology as the "science of mental life." This definition is still useful today. Everyone has a mental life, which means we have some understanding of our thoughts and feelings. Psychology can be studied in humans, rats, and monkeys, but it can be hard to understand completely. James focused on human psychology, which he believed included basic elements like thoughts, feelings, the physical world, and how we know about these things. Our knowledge is mostly personal and comes from our own experiences, which may or may not match scientific facts.

Because of this, we often make judgments about psychological issues based on our own experiences. We act like amateur psychologists when we share our opinions on complex topics, such as whether brainwashing works or why people behave in certain ways. Problems can arise when two people understand things differently. Formal psychology tries to provide methods to find the most likely correct explanations in different situations. Psychologists help us tell the difference between our subjective thoughts, which can be biased, and objective facts.

Psychology, as defined by William James, is about the mind and brain. While psychologists study the brain, they do not yet fully understand how it works in relation to our feelings and behaviors. It is often difficult to study the brain directly, so psychologists learn more by observing behavior and making educated guesses about what happens inside us. A challenge in psychology is that scientific facts should be objective, but we cannot observe the mind in the same way we can observe a machine. We can only see the mind's effects through behavior.

Studying psychology is like solving a crossword puzzle. It requires careful observation, accurate measurement, and logical thinking. Psychology aims to describe, understand, predict, and learn how to change the processes it studies. When psychologists achieve these goals, they can help us understand our experiences and apply this knowledge to real life. Psychological research has helped improve teaching methods, design safer machines, and support people dealing with emotional distress.

Although people have discussed psychological questions for centuries, scientific investigation of these questions has only happened in the last 150 years. Early psychologists used introspection, which means looking at one’s own thoughts and feelings, to find answers. While this method is still interesting, it has limitations. Sir Francis Galton noted that introspection only shows a small part of what the brain does automatically. William James compared trying to understand the mind through introspection to "turning up the gas quickly enough to see how the darkness looks." Today, psychologists prefer to base their theories on careful observations of others' behavior rather than just their own experiences.

Text: In a storehouse in a simple business park in Michigan, USA, there is a place that shows the failures of consumer products. This place is informally called the Museum of Failed Products. It has items that were taken off the market because very few people wanted to buy them. The museum is owned by a company called GfK, and its owner, Carol Sherry, believes that each product has a sad story about the designers and marketers who created it.

What is surprising is that this museum exists as a business. You might think that any good manufacturer would keep a collection of their failed products. However, many business leaders do not want to think about their failures and often do not keep samples of their unsuccessful products. The museum started by accident. Robert McMath, a former marketing professional, wanted to create a library of consumer products, not just failed ones. Starting in the 1960s, he began to buy every new item he could find. He did not realize that most products fail. By collecting all kinds of new products, he ended up with mostly unsuccessful ones.

Today’s culture of optimism may explain why many products end up in the museum. Each product likely went through meetings where people did not see that it would fail. Even if they did, marketers might spend more money on a failing product to try to make it sell better. Little effort is made to understand why the products failed, and people involved often choose not to talk about it again.

This focus on being positive is also common in the self-help industry. One popular idea is "positive visualization," which suggests that if you imagine good outcomes, they are more likely to happen. Some scientists believe that our brains are wired to see things positively, which may help us survive. Research by neuroscientist Tali Sharot shows that people with a healthy mindset often have an overly optimistic view of their ability to influence events compared to those who are depressed.

However, how effective are these positive thoughts about the future? Psychologist Gabriele Oettingen and her team have studied this question. Their findings are surprising: thinking too much about how well things could go can actually reduce people's motivation to reach their goals. For example, people who were encouraged to imagine having a very successful week at work ended up achieving less.

Psychologist Carol Dweck explains that our experiences with failure depend on our beliefs about ability. People with a "fixed mindset" believe that ability is something you are born with, while those with a "growth mindset" think that ability can develop through effort and challenges. People with a fixed mindset find failure very scary because it shows they did not meet expectations. For example, a sports star who thinks he is naturally talented may not practice enough to succeed. On the other hand, people with a growth mindset see failure as a sign that they are pushing their limits. Dweck compares this to weight training: muscles grow stronger when they are pushed to their limits, where they tear and heal. Having a growth mindset is a happier way to live, whether or not it leads to success.

Text: 

Everyone knows that sports teams have an advantage when they play at home. But why is that? Many people think they know the answer, but professional sports are changing quickly, and what we used to believe is now being questioned. Two main reasons for this are science and money. Sports scientists want to understand what helps players perform their best, and they have many ideas about home advantage. At the same time, people who invest in sports want to know why home advantage is still important. If players are paid enough, shouldn’t they feel comfortable playing anywhere?

What about the fans? Would it matter if a team like Manchester United played some of their home games far away, like in the Far East, to reach more fans? It would matter to British fans who believe their team needs their support and loyalty. Fans often think that the order of events explains what happens. For example, when a team plays well, the home fans cheer loudly, and sometimes this leads to a goal. Fans remember the times they cheered and a goal was scored, but they forget the many times when their cheering did not lead to a goal.

There is one common belief among fans that science supports. Home fans not only cheer for their team but also direct a lot of their noise at the referee. In a famous study, referees watched a match with crowd noise and another group watched the same match in silence. The referees who heard the crowd were less likely to call fouls against the home team. This shows that referees try to avoid making calls that would upset the home crowd.

Recent studies show that home advantage has decreased in many sports, but not as much as expected. For example, in the early years of the Football League in England, home teams won about 70% of the points, while today they win about 60%. One reason for this change could be travel. In the past, traveling was difficult, but now players travel in comfort, and if their hotel is not good enough, the club will find them a better one. Stadiums also look more similar now, which may affect the home advantage.

However, these explanations do not fully explain the data. Home advantage varies by sport. Basketball has the most home advantage, followed by football, while baseball has the least. One reason could be that home advantage is more about teamwork, and baseball focuses more on individual players. In team sports like basketball, players need to work together, and playing at home helps build their confidence.

Another interesting point is about players' testosterone levels. Researchers found that players' testosterone levels were normal before away games but were much higher before home games. This increase may be linked to a natural desire to protect their home ground. In recent Rugby World Cup games, underdog teams won at home against stronger teams, showing the power of home advantage. As one referee said, "It’s the law of the jungle out there."

Text: "‘The more I practice, the luckier I get,’ said golfer Gary Player many years ago. This saying is famous in sports and is important to many athletes and their coaches. It is easy to understand why. First, there is some debate about who really said it first, as many golfers from that time have been mentioned. Second, the meaning of the quote is not clear. Player did not mean luck in a real sense; he was being ironic. His real message was: ‘The more I practice, the better I get.’ 

However, there is a question about how much practice is needed to improve. This question is part of a bigger discussion about whether talent is something we are born with or something we can develop through practice. This discussion is not balanced; it seems that practice is more important than natural talent. The idea that practice is more important than talent comes from psychologist Anders Ericsson. He is known for the theory that you can become an expert in any field with 10,000 hours of practice. This idea has been popularized in books like Malcolm Gladwell’s Outliers and others that say talent is not as important as practice.

But, as Epstein discusses in his interesting book, this idea is not always true. He points out a problem in many studies about successful people: they often only look at those who are already excellent. He asks if there are other ways to understand why some people have certain skills while others do not. Epstein travels around the world, from Kenya to Sweden and beyond, to find answers. In Alaska, he learns that in the toughest sled dog race, the drive and desire of the husky dogs may be very important. This suggests that both genes and learned traits can play a role.

Some people believe that commitment and determination are choices we make. But what if, as Epstein suggests with the huskies, a person’s drive is also influenced by their genes? This shows how complex the topic is. Epstein talks about the difference between nature (genes) and nurture (environment), and he believes that both are important for elite athletes. He does not ignore the role of training or environment. For example, he thinks that if Usain Bolt had grown up in the US, he might have been a good basketball player instead of the fastest man in the world.

Epstein also looks at important issues like race and gender. He asks, ‘If only practice matters, why do we separate men and women in sports competitions?’ Sometimes, the best questions are the most obvious."

**Simplified Text:**

A recent international report shows that many children living in rich countries feel lonely and unhappy. Jay Griffiths asks a simple question: why are today’s children so sad? In her new book, *Kith*, Griffiths explains that these children spend too much time indoors, looking at screens like televisions and computers. They have lost touch with nature, such as forests, mountains, and rivers. She believes this is a big part of the problem.

A follow-up study interviewed some children to understand their feelings better. The study found that many children do not want more technology; instead, they would be happier if they could go outside more. Many adults over 40 remember their own childhoods fondly, saying they enjoyed playing outside, swimming in ponds, and exploring. They think this was much better and healthier than the lives of children today. However, they often forget that they are the ones who have kept their children safe and indoors, worrying about dangers outside.

Griffiths discusses the fear parents have about letting their children play outside and how this fear helps companies sell toys and gadgets to keep children entertained at home. She also talks about trends like giving medicine to children who are restless or making them wear goggles during games. While it is unclear how common these rules are, Griffiths expresses her strong feelings about them. She also shares her thoughts on childhood freedoms and rules, from fairy tales to school regulations.

Although Griffiths makes interesting points, she sometimes goes too far. She compares how children are treated today to a form of racism, which seems extreme. She has a romantic view of children, believing they are naturally good and creative. However, this view may not match the reality of how children behave in groups.

One important idea in the book is that children should be allowed to explore and take risks. Griffiths believes that children need to experience small accidents to learn how to handle bigger dangers later. However, she does not explain how to create these small accidents safely. Also, not all children want to explore the wild as Griffiths suggests. What about children who are shy or prefer to stay at home? Perhaps the real problem is that we try to make all children fit into the same mold, whether by keeping them inside or pushing them outside.

**Simplified Text:**

I am a bio-psychologist with a PhD, which means I have studied a lot. I am good at solving problems in my work and life, but this is not just because of my education. Many problems in life cannot be solved with complicated formulas or answers we memorize in school. They need judgment, wisdom, and creativity that come from life experiences. For children, these experiences happen during play. 

My recent research focuses on how important play is for children's development. All mammals, including humans, play when they are young. Those who have more to learn tend to play more. For example, carnivores (meat-eaters) play more than herbivores (plant-eaters) because hunting is harder to learn than grazing. Primates, like monkeys and apes, play more than other mammals because they need to learn more and rely less on instincts. Children, who have a lot to learn, play more than any other young primates when they can.

Play is a natural way for both adults and mammals to learn. The most important skills children need to live happy and productive lives cannot be taught in school. These skills are learned and practiced through play. They include thinking creatively, getting along with others, cooperating, and controlling their emotions. Creativity is very important for success in today’s world. We do not need people who just follow instructions or do simple calculations. We need people who can ask new questions and solve new problems. If we can help people think ahead and find solutions, we will have a strong workforce. But this requires creative thinking, which comes from a playful mind.

Adults we call geniuses are those who keep their childlike ability to be creative. Albert Einstein said that school almost took away his interest in math and physics, but he found it again after leaving school. He called his innovative work “combinatorial play.” He imagined chasing a sunbeam and thought about what would happen next. 

We cannot teach creativity, but we can lose it through schooling that focuses only on questions from a strict curriculum, where there is only one right answer. More important than creativity is the ability to get along with others, care for them, and cooperate. Children are born wanting to play with others, and through play, they learn social skills, fairness, and morality, which they will need later in life.

Play is voluntary, which means players can stop whenever they want. If you cannot stop, it is not play. Players know they must keep each other happy to continue the game. This ability to quit makes play a very democratic activity.

School has become harder: there are fewer breaks, more homework, and more pressure for high grades. Outside of school, organized sports have taken the place of spontaneous games. “Play dates” with adults have replaced unsupervised play in neighborhoods, and adults often feel they must step in instead of letting children solve their own problems. These changes have happened slowly but have had a big impact over time. They are caused by many social factors, including parents’ fears, warnings from experts about dangers, less connected neighborhoods, and the belief that children learn more from adults than from each other.

Our children do not need more school. They need more play. If we care about our children and future generations, we must change the negative trend of the past fifty years. We must give childhood back to children. They should be allowed to play and explore so they can grow into strong adults ready for an unpredictable future.

In many countries, more young people in their twenties are using social media to find jobs. Websites like Twitter and LinkedIn allow them to connect directly with potential employers. This is different from the old way of trying to get noticed by standing outside an office with a sign saying "hire me." However, using social media can also lead to mistakes. 

For example, a young job seeker in the US tried to connect with a senior marketing executive on LinkedIn. This executive had many important contacts, and the job seeker thought she could help him. But the executive was upset by his request. She refused to connect with him and sent a rude message that became very popular online. Many people were shocked by her response, and she might regret how she wrote it. However, if this incident makes young people think more carefully about using social media for work, it could be helpful.

Social media can be risky for job seekers who do not know how to use it properly. Many young people are making mistakes. This is surprising because social networking sites like Facebook and Twitter have been a big part of young people's social lives for years. When older generations were teenagers, social media was a way to escape from parents and teachers. It was a place to show off and be creative. You could have long conversations online and then ignore the same person at school. With the right pictures and songs on Facebook, you could seem like a different person. 

But using social media for professional networking is very different. Some young people do not see this difference. They learned to be bold and confident online, which might make them think this is still a good approach. Just because many people liked your posts on Facebook does not mean you can impress employers on LinkedIn. Young people need to understand that the rules of social networking have changed, and they must meet employers' expectations to succeed in their careers.

One common complaint from employers is that young job seekers are too casual in their messages and seem arrogant. This makes older generations think young people feel entitled. In reality, many young people are worried about finding jobs, which is why they use social media. This impression of arrogance can hurt their chances, even if they have the skills and motivation to be good employees.

So, how should you contact someone on a professional networking site? First, clearly explain who you are and what you can offer them, like doing some research or helping in another way. This can help you get a better response. Avoid sending generic messages, and keep your tone polite to make a good impression. Remember, social media can help you make important connections, but you need to use it carefully to avoid being ignored.

Text: "Anyone who says they can predict the future of newspapers is either lying or mistaken. The numbers show that newspapers are in trouble. Since 2000, the number of copies sold by most UK national daily newspapers has dropped by one-third to one-half. The Pew Research Centre in the USA says that newspapers are now the main source of news for only 26 percent of US citizens, down from 45 percent in 2001. Many people believe that the last printed newspaper will disappear within 15 years. However, history shows that old forms of media often survive. In 1835, a journalist in New York claimed that books and theatre were finished and that daily newspapers would be the most important source of news. But theatre survived, even with the rise of newspapers, cinema, and television. Radio has also done well during the TV era, and cinema has continued to thrive despite videos and DVDs. Even vinyl records have become popular again, with online sales increasing by 745 percent since 2008. 

Newspapers were once a new form of media, but it took centuries for them to become the main source of news. This change happened because it became possible and affordable to produce news for many people over large areas in the mid-19th century, thanks to the steam press, railways, and telegraphs. It was also important that people began to understand that the world is always changing and that they need regular updates. In medieval times, people did not think this way. They only saw the changing seasons and unexpected disasters like famine or disease. Life was seen as a cycle, with repeating events. 

Before the 19th century, journalism was not a full-time job that people could rely on for a living. Even then, most people did not see the need for news every day or week. The regular publication of newspapers can sometimes feel limiting. Online news allows readers to choose when and how they want to read, based on what they find important. Advanced search engines help us find news that matches our interests. When big news happens, online news can provide updates every minute. Mistakes and misunderstandings can be corrected quickly. There are no limits on space, so stories can be longer and more detailed. 

This is very different from the strict format of newspapers. However, many news providers do not seem to use the internet's ability to help people understand the news better. Instead, they focus on being the first to report news, getting more comments, and creating excitement, which can lead to confusion. In medieval times, news was often shared in busy places like markets or taverns, where truth mixed with rumors and misunderstandings. In some ways, we seem to be going back to that situation. Newspapers have not always been very good at explaining how the world works. They might be facing extinction. Or maybe, as the internet adds to our feeling that we live in a chaotic world, newspapers will find a way to help us understand and gain wisdom."

**Simplified Text:**

If humans really felt at home under the moon and stars, we would walk happily in the dark, just like many animals that are active at night. But we are daytime creatures, with eyes that are made for sunlight. This fact is part of our nature, even if we don’t think about it. It helps explain what we have done to the night. We have changed the night by adding light. This control is similar to building a dam on a river. While there are benefits to this, it also creates problems called light pollution, which scientists are just starting to study.

Light pollution happens mostly because of poor lighting design. This means that artificial light shines into the sky instead of down where it is needed. Bad lighting brightens the night and changes the light levels that many living things, including us, have adapted to. When man-made light spreads into nature, it affects important activities like migration, reproduction, and feeding.

For most of human history, the term ‘light pollution’ would not have made sense. Imagine walking towards London on a moonlit night around 1800, when it was the most populated city in the world. Almost a million people lived there, using candles, torches, and lanterns. Only a few houses had gas lights, and there were no public gas lights in the streets for another seven years. From a distance, you would have smelled London more than you would have seen its faint glow.

We have lit up the night as if it were empty, but that is not true. There are many nocturnal animals. Light is a strong force in nature, and it attracts many species. Scientists say that some birds are ‘captured’ by bright lights, circling around them until they fall. Birds that migrate at night often crash into tall buildings that are brightly lit, and young birds are especially affected. Some birds, like blackbirds and nightingales, sing at strange times because of artificial light.

At first, it was thought that light pollution only bothered astronomers, who need to see the night sky clearly. Most of us may not need to see the stars for our work, but we still need darkness. Not having darkness is not good for us. It is just as important for our health as light is. Changing our natural sleep and wake cycles can cause health problems. The regular pattern of waking and sleeping is a natural response to the light and dark on Earth. These patterns are so important that changing them is like changing our balance.

In the end, humans are just as affected by light pollution as frogs living near a bright highway. By living in our own bright lights, we have lost touch with our natural and cultural history – the light of the stars and the natural rhythms of day and night. Light pollution makes us forget our true place in the universe and the vastness of our existence, which is best understood under a dark sky filled with stars.

Text: 

The founder of a large international company recently said that his business will no longer keep track of how much paid holiday time employees take. This decision seems to be inspired by a smaller internet company that has a similar policy. The founder mentioned that he got the idea from a happy email from his daughter, which many newspapers have shared. However, some people think that this way of announcing the change seems like a way to make a difficult decision look better. 

Is this idea practical? The internet company has 2,000 employees and offers one service, while the multinational corporation has 50,000 employees and many different services, like finance, transport, and healthcare. The idea of "take as much time off as you want" might work better in a smaller company where employees know each other’s work schedules. In a big company, it can be hard to know if taking time off will hurt the business. The founder said that employees can take as much leave as they want, as long as they feel sure that their work and their team are up to date. But is it really possible to be that sure? 

No matter how much work you finish before a holiday, there will always be more work waiting when you return. This is just how taking leave works; you pause your work, but it keeps building up. If employees follow these new rules, they might not take any time off or feel guilty about taking leave. Feeling guilty can lead to stress, and if workers do not take enough time off, it could lower their productivity over time. 

There may also be pressure from coworkers and gossip about who is taking time off and for how long. This pressure can affect when people start and end their workday. In many companies, there is a culture of working late, which could lead to a "no holiday" culture in a place with unlimited leave, where employees compete for promotions. If workers feel they cannot take the leave they need, they might worry about looking lazy. They would lose the legal right to take time off, which could make them feel stuck. 

Modern technology makes it easy to receive work messages anytime and anywhere, mixing work and free time. The internet company started their unlimited leave policy because employees wanted to know how to balance this new way of working with the old rules about time off. If the company cannot track how much time employees work, why should they have different rules for time off? 

However, not having set working hours can be a problem because it means that all hours could be working hours. Employees might not know if their working hours are being watched, which can make them feel like they have to work all the time. Employment laws exist for a reason. Workers have the right to a minimum amount of paid leave because rest and free time are important for their health. 

The benefits of unlimited leave, like better morale and creativity, can happen without sacrificing worker well-being. Therefore, I am not sure if the idea of "taking as much holiday as they want" is really what this policy is about or if it will actually happen.
